note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

div.head: THE WOMANS PRIZE: OR, The Tamer Tamed.
Scaena Prima.
div.stage: Enter Moroſo, Sophocles, and Tranio, with Roſemary, as from a wedding.

sp.speaker: Moroſo.
sp.l: _GOd give 'em joy.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Amen.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Amen, ſay I to:
The Puddings now i'th proof; alas poor wench,
Through what a mine of patience muſt thou worke,
Ere thou know'ſt good houre more?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Tis too true: Certaine,
Me thinks her father has dealt harſhly with her,
Exceeding harſhly, and not like a Father,
To match her to this Dragon; I proteſt
I pity the poore Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Me thinks now,
He's not ſo terrible as people think him.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: This old thiefe flatters, out of meere devotion,
To pleaſe the father for his ſecond daughter.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: But ſhall he have her?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Yes, when I have Rome.
And yet the father's for him.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Ile aſſure ye,
I hold him a good man.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Yes ſure a wealthy,
But whether a good womans man, is doubtfull.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Would 'twere no worſe.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: What though his other wife,
Out of her moſt abundant ſoberneſſe,
Out of her daily huy and cries upon him,
(For ſure ſhe was a Rebell) turn'd his temper,
And forc'd him blow as high as ſhe? do'ſt follow
He muſt retain that long ſince buried Tempeſt,
To this ſoft maid?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: I feare it.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: So do I too:
And ſo far, that if God had made me woman,
And his wife that muſt be—

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: What would you doe ſir?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I would learn to eate Coales with an angry Cat,
And ſpit fire at him: I would (to prevent him)
Do all the ramping, roaring tricks, a whore
Being drunke, and tumbling ripe, would tremble at:
There is no ſafety elſe, nor morall wiſdome,
To be a wife, and his.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: So I ſhould think too.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: For yet the bare remembrance of his firſt wife
(I tell ye on my knowledge, and a truth too)
Will make him ſtart in's ſleep, and very often
Cry out for Cudgels, Colſtaves, any thing;
Hiding his Breeches, out of feare her Ghoſt
Should walk, and weare 'em yet. Since his firſt marriage,
He is no more the ſtill Petruchio,
Then I am Babylon.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: He's a good felloW,
And on my word I love him: but to think
A fit match for this tender ſoule—

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: His very frowne, if ſhe but ſay her prayers
Louder then men talk treaſon, makes him tindar;
The motion of a Diall, when he's teſty,
Is the ſame trouble to him as a water-worke;
She muſt do nothing of her ſelfe; not eate,
Drink, ſay ſir how do ye, make her ready, unready,
Unleſſe he bid her.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: He will bury her
Ten pound to twenty ſhillings, within theſe three weeks.

sp.speaker: Tra:
sp.l: Ile be your halfe.

div.stage: Enter Jaques with a pot of Wine.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: He loves her moſt extreamly,
And ſo long 'twil be honey-moon. Now Jaques
You are a buſie man I am ſure.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Yes certaine,
This old ſport muſt have egges,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Not yet this ten daies.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Sweet Gentlemen with Muskadell.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: That's right ſir.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: This fellow broods his Maſter: ſpeed ye Jaques.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: We ſhall be for you preſently.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Your worſhips
Shal have it rich and neat: and o' my conſcience
As welcom as our Lady day: O my old ſir,
When ſhall we ſee your worſhip run at Ring?
That houre a ſtanding were worth money

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: So ſir.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Upon my little honeſty, your Miſtris,
If I have any ſpeculation, muſt thinke
This ſingle thrumming of a Fiddle,
Without a Bow, but ev'n poore ſport.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Y'are merry.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Would I were wiſe too: ſo God bleſs your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: The fellow tels you true. Exit Jaq.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: When is the day man?
Come, come, you'l ſteale a marriage.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Nay believe me:
But when her father pleaſes I am ready,
And all my friends ſhall know it.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Why not now?
One charge had ſerv'd for both.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: There's reaſon in't.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Call'd Rowland.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Will ye walke?
They'l think we are loſt: Come Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: You have wip't him now.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: So will he never the wench I hope.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I wiſh it. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Now Livia, if you'l goe away to night,
If your affections be not made of words.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: I love you, and you know how dearly Rowland,
Is there none neere us? my affections ever
Have been your ſervants; with what ſuperſtition
I have ever Sainted you—

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Why then take this way.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Twill be a childiſh and a leſſe proſperous courſe,
Then his that knows not care: why ſhould we do
Our honeſt and our hearty love ſuch wrong,
To over-run our fortunes?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Then you flatter.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Alas you know I cannot.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: What hopes left elſe
But flying to enjoy ye?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: None ſo far,
For let it be admitted we have time,
And all things now in other expectation,
My father's bent againſt us; what but ruine,
Can ſuch a by-way bring us? if your feares
Would let you look with my eyes, I would ſhew you,
And certain, how our ſtaying here would win us
A courſe, though ſomewhat longer, yet far ſurer.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: And then Moroſo h'as ye.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: No ſuch matter:
For hold this certaine, begging, ſtealing, whoring,
Selling, (which is a ſin unpardonable)
Of counterfeit Cods, or muſty Engliſh Crac●s,
Switches, or ſtones for th'toothache ſooner finds me,
Then that drawn Fox and Moroſo.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: But his money,
If wealth may win you—

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: If a Hog may be
High Prieſt among the Jewes: his money Rowland?
Oh Love forgive me, what faith haſt thou?
Why, can his money kiſſe me?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Behind,
Laſd out upon a Petticote: or graſpe me
While I cry, O good thank you? o' my troth
Thou makſt me merry with thy feare: or lie with me,
As you may do? alas, what fooles you men are?
His mouldy money? half a dozen Riders,
That cannot ſit but ſtampt faſt to their Saddles?
No Rowland, no man ſhall make uſe of me;
My beauty was born free, and free Ile give it
To him that loves, not buys me. You yet doubt me.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: I cannot ſay I doubt ye.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Goe thy waies,
Thou art the prettieſt puling piece of paſſion:
Y faith I will not faile thee.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: I had rather—

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Prethee believe me, if I do not carry it,
For both our goods—

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: But—

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: What but?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: I would tell you.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: I know all you can tell me; all's but this,
You would have me, and lie with me; is't not ſo?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Why you ſhall; will that content you? Goe.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: I am very loth to goe. Enter Byancha, and Maria.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Now o' my conſcience
Thou art an honeſt fellow: here's my ſiſter;
Go, prethee goe; this kiſſe, and credit me,
Ere I am three nights older, I am for thee:
You ſhall heare what I do.
Farewell.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Farewell. Exit Rowland.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Alas poore foole, how it looks?
It would ev'n hang it ſelfe, ſhould I but croſſe it.
For pure love to the matter I muſt hatch it.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Nay never look for merry houre Maria,
If now you make it not; let not your bluſhes,
Your modeſty, and tenderneſſe of ſpirit,
Make you continuall Anvile to his anger:
Believe me, ſince his firſt wife ſet him going,
Nothing can bind his rage: Take your own Councell,
You ſhall not ſay that I perſwaded you.
But if you ſuffer him—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Stay, ſhall I do it?

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Have you a ſtomack to't?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I never ſhew'd it.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Twill ſhew the rarer, and the ſtronger in you.
But do not ſay I urg'd you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I am perfect,
Like Curtius to redeeme my Countrey, have I
Leap'd into this gulph of marriage, and Ile do it.
Farewell all poorer thoughts, but ſpight & anger,
Till I have wrought a miracle. Now coſen,
I am no more the gentle tame Maria;
Miſtake me not; I have a new ſoule in me
Made of a North-wind, nothing but tempeſt;
And like a tempeſt ſhall it make all ruins,
Till I have run my will out.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: This is brave now,
If you continue it; but your own will lead you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Adieu all tenderneſſe, I dare continue;
Maides that are made of feares and modeſt bluſhes,
View me, and love example.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Here is your ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Here is the brave old mans love.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: That loves the young man.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I and hold thee there wench: what a grief of heart is't,
When Papbos Rebels ſhould up rowſe old night,
To ſweat againſt a Cork; to lie and tell
The clock o'th longs, to riſe ſport-ſtarv'd?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Deere ſiſter,
Where have you been you talke thus?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why at Church, wench;
Where I am tide to talke thus: I am a wife now.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: It ſeems ſo, and a modeſt.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You are an aſſe;
When thou art married once, thy modeſty
Will never buy thee Pins.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: 'Bleſſe me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: From what?

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: From ſuch a tame foole as our cozen Livia?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: You are not mad.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes wench, and ſo muſt you be,
Or none of our acquantance, marke me Livia.
Or indeed ſit for our ſex: Tis bed time.
Pardon me yellow Hymen, that I meane
Thine offrings to protract, or to keepe faſting
My valiant Bridegroome.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Whether will this woman?

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: You may perceive her end.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Or rather feare it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Dare you be partner in't?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Leave it Maria,
I feare I have mark'd too much, for goodneſſe leave it;
Deveſt you with obedient hands to bed.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: To bed? No Livia, there are Comets hang
Prodigious over that yet; there's a fellow
Muſt yet before I know that heat (nere ſtart wench)
Be male a man, for yet he is a monſter;
Here muſt his head be Livia.

sp.speaker: Liv
sp.l: Never hope it.
Tis as eaſie with a Sive to ſcoope the Ocean, as
To tame Petruchio.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Stay: Lucina heare me,
Never unlock the treaſure of my womb
For humane fruit, to make it capable;
Nor never with thy ſecret hand make briefe
A mothers labour to me; if I doe
Give way unto my married husbands will,
Or be a wife, in any thing but hopes,
Till I have made him eaſie as a child,
And tame as feare, he ſhall not win a ſmile,
Or a pleas'd look, from this auſterity,
Though it would pull another Joynture from him,
And make him ev'ry day another man;
And when I kiſſe him, till I have my will,
May I be barren of delights, and know
Onely what pleaſures are in dreams, and gueſſes.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: A ſtrange Exordium.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: All the ſeverall wrongs
Done by Emperious husbands to their wives
Theſe thouſand yeeres and upwards, ſtrengthen thee:
Thou haſt a brave cauſe.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And Ile doe it bravely
Or may I knit my life out ever after.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: In what part of the world got ſhe this ſpirit?
Yet pray Maria, looke before you truly,
Beſides the obedience of a wife,
Which you will finde a heavy imputation,
Which yet I cannot thinke your own, it ſhews
So diſtant from your ſweetneſſe.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Tis I ſweare.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Weigh but the perſon, and the hopes you have,
To worke this diſperate cure.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: A weaker ſubject
Would ſhame the end I aime at, diſobedience.
You talk too tamely: By the faith I have
In mine own Noble will, that childiſh woman
That lives a priſoner to her husbands pleaſure,
Has loſt her making, and becomes a beaſt,
Created for his uſe, not fellowſhip.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: His firſt wife ſaid as much.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: She was a foole,
And took a ſcurvy courſe; let her be nam'd
'Mongſt thoſe that wiſh for things, but dare not do 'em:
I have a new daunce for him.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Are you of this faith?

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Yes truly, and wil die in't.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Why then let's all weare breeches.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Now thou comſt neere the nature of a woman;
Hang theſe tame hearted Eyaſſes, that no ſooner
See the Lure out, and heare their husbands halla,
But cry like Kites upon 'em: The free Haggard
(Which is that woman, that hath wing, and knowes it,
Spirit, and plume) wil make an hundred checks,
To ſhew her freedome, ſaile in ev'ry ayre,
And look out ev'ry pleaſure; not regarding
I ure, nor quarry, till her pitch command
What ſhe deſires, making her foundred keeper
Be glad to fling out traines, and golden ones,
To take her down again.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: You are learned ſiſter;
Yet I ſay ſtill take heed.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: A witty ſaying;
Ile tell thee Livia, had this fellow tired
As many wives as horſes under him,
With ſpurring of their patience; had he got
A Patent, with an Office to reclaime us
Confirm'd by Parliament; had he all the malice
And ſubtilty of Devils, or of us,
Or any thing that's worſe then both.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Hey, hey boyes, this is excellent.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Or could he
Caſt his wives new again, like Bels to make 'em
Sound to his will; or had the fearfull name
Of the firſt breaker of wilde women: yet,
Yet would I undertake this man, thus ſingle,
And ſpight of all the freedom he has reach'd to,
Turn him and bend him as I liſt, and mold him
Into a babe again; that aged women,
Wanting both teeth & ſpleen, may Maſter him.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Thou wilt be chronicl'd.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: That's all I aime at.

sp.speaker: Liv
sp.l: I muſt confeſſe, I do with all my heart
Hate an Emperious husband, and in time
Might be ſo wrought upon.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: To make him cuckold?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: If he deſerve it.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Then Ile leave ye Ladies.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Thou haſt not ſo much Noble anger in thee.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Goe ſleep, goe ſleep, what we intend to do,
Lies not for ſuch ſtarv'd ſoules as thou haſt Livia.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Good night: the Bridegroom will be with you preſently.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: That's more then you know.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: If ye worke upon him,
As you have promiſed, ye may give example,
Which no doubt will be followed.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Good night: we'l trouble you no further.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: If you intend no good, pray doe no harm.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: None, but pray for you. Exit Livia.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: 'Cheere wench?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Now Byancha,
Thoſe wits we have let's wind 'em to the height,
My reſt is up wench, and I pull for that
Will make me ever famous. They that lay
Foundations, are halfe builders all men ſay.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: My Maſter forſooth.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Oh how do's thy Maſter? prethee commend me to him.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: How's this? my Maſter ſtaies forſooth.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why let him ſtay, who hinders him forſooth?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: The Revel's ended now,
To viſit you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I am not ſick.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: I mean to ſee his chamber, forſooth.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Am I his Groom? where lay he laſt night, forſooth?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: In the low matted Parlour.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: There lies his way by the long Gallery.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: I mean your chamber: y'ar very merry Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Tis a good ſigne I am ſound hearted Jaques:
But if you'l know where I lie, follow me;
And what thou ſeeſt, deliver to thy Maſter.

sp.speaker: Bja.
sp.l: Do gentle Jaques. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: Ha, is the wind in that dore?
By'r Lady we ſhall have foule weather then:
I doe not like the ſhuffling of theſe women,
They are mad beaſts when they knock their heads together:
I have obſerv'd them all this day; their whiſpers,
One in anothers eare, their ſignes, and pinches,
And breaking often into violent laughters:
As if the end they purpos'd were their own.
Call you this weddings? Sure this is a knavery,
A very trick, and dainty knavery,
Marvellous finely carried, that's the comfort:
What would theſe women doe in waies of honour,
That are ſuch Maſters this way. Well, my Sir
Has been as good at finding out theſe toyes,
As any living; if he loſe it now,
At his own perill be it. I muſt follow. Exit.

div.head: Scena tertia.
div.stage: Enter Servants with lights, Petruchio, Petronius, Moroſo, Tranio, and Sophocles.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: You that are married, Gentlemen, home at ye
For a round wager now.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Of this nights Stage?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: I am your firſt man: a paire of Gloves of twenty ſhillings.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Done: who takes me up next? I am for all bets.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Well luſty Laurence, were but my night now,
Old as I am, I would make you clap on Spurs,
But I would reach you, and bring you to your trot too:
I would Gallants.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Well ſaid good Will; but where's the ſtaffe boy, ha?
Old father time, your houre-glaſſe is empty.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: A good tough traine would break thee all to pieces;
Thou haſt not breath enough to ſay thy prayers.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Set how theſe boyes deſpiſe us. Will you to bed ſonne?
This pride will have a fall.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Upon your daughter;
But I ſhall riſe again, if there be truth
In Egges, and butter'd Paſnips.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Wil you to bed ſon, & leave talking;
To morrow morning we ſhall have you looke,
For all your great words, like St. George at Kingſton,
Running a foot-back from the furious Dragon,
That with her angry tayle belabours him
For being lazie.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: His courage quench'd, and ſo far quench'd—

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Tis well ſir.
What then?

sp.speaker: Saph.
sp.l: Fly, fly, quoth then the fearfull dwarfe;
Here is no place for living man.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.p: Well my maſters, if I doe ſinke under my buſi|neſſe, as I finde tis very poſſible, I am not the firſt that has miſcarried; So that's my comfort, what may be done without impeach or waſte, I can and will doe.
sp.l: How now is my faire Bride a bed?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: No truly ſir.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.p: Not a bed yet? body o' me: we'l up and rifle her: here's a coyle with a mayden-head, tis not intayl'd, is it?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.p: If it be, ile try all the Law i'th Land, but Ile cut it off: let's up, let's up, come.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: That you cannot neither.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Unleſſe you'll drop through the Chimney like a Daw, or force a breach i'th windows: you may untile the houſe, tis poſſible.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: What doſt thou meane?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: A morall ſir, the Ballat will expreſſe it:

l.hi: The wind and the rain has turnd you back again,

sp.l: And you cannot be lodged there. The truth is all the doores
Are baracadoed; not a Cathole, but holds a murd'rer in't.
She's victual'd for this moneth.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Art not thou drunk?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: He's drunk, he's drunk; come, come, let's up.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I am drunke: ye may goe up, ye may Gentlemen, but take heed to your heads: I ſay no more.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Ile try that. Exit Soph.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: How doſt thou ſay? the door faſt lock'd fellow?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Yes truly ſir, tis lock'd, and guarded too; and two as deſperate tongues planted behind it, as ere yet batterd: they ſtand upon their honours, and will not give up without ſtrange compoſition, Ile aſſure you; marching away with their Pieces cockt, and Bullets in their mouthes will not ſatisfie them.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: How's this? how's this they are?
Is there another with her?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Yes marry is there, and an Engineir.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Who's that for Heavens ſake?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.p: Colonell Byancha, ſhe commands the workes: Spinala's but a ditcher to her, there's a halfe-moon; I am but a poore man, but if you'l give me leave, Ile venture a yeeres wages, draw all your force before it, and mount your ableſt piece of battery, you ſhall not enter it theſe three nights yet.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: I ſhould laugh at that good Jaques.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Beat back again, ſhe's fortified for ever.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Am I drunk now ſir?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: He that dares moſt, goe up now, and be cool'd.
I have ſcap'd a pretty ſcowring.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.p: What are they mad? have we another Bedlam? They doe not talke I hope?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Oh terribly, extreamly fearfull, the noiſe at Lon|don-bridge is nothing neere her.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: How got ſhe tongue?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: As you got taile, ſhe was born to't.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Lock'd out a doors, and on my wedding-night?
Nay, and I ſuffer this, I may goe graze:
Come Gentlemen, Ile batter; are theſe vertues?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: Do, and be beaten off with ſhame, as I was: I went up, came to th' doore, knockd, no body anſwered; knock'd lowder, yet heard nothing: would have broke in by force; when ſuddenly a water-worke flew from the window with ſuch violence, that had I not duck'd quickly like a Fryer, caetera quis neſcit? The chamber's nothing but a meere Oſtend, in every window Pewter cannons mounted, you'l quickly finde with what they are charg'd, ſir.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Why then tantara for us.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.p: And all the lower works lin'd ſure with ſmall ſhot, long tongues with Fire-locks, that at twelve ſcore blanke hit to the heart: now and ye dare go up

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: The window opens, beat a parley firſt;
I am ſo much amaz'd my very haire ſtands.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Why how now daughter: what intrenc'd?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: A little guarded for my ſafety ſir.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: For your ſafety Sweet-heart why who offends you?
I come not to uſe violence.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I thinke you cannot ſir, I am better fortified.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: I know your end,
You would faine reprieve your Maiden-head
A night, or two.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes, or ten, or twenty, or ſay an hundred;
Or indeed, till I liſt lie with you.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: That's a ſhrewd ſaying; from this preſent houre,
I never will believe a ſilent woman.
When they break out they are bonfires.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Till you liſt lie with him? why who are you Madam?

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: That trim Gentlemans wife, ſir.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Cry you mercy, do you command too?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes marry do's ſhe, and in chiefe.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: I doe command, and you ſhall go without:
(I mean your wife, for this night)

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And for the next too wench, and ſo as't follows.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Thou wilt not, wilt 'a?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes indeed deere father,
And till he ſeale to what I ſhall ſet down,
For any thing I know, for ever.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Indeed theſe are Bugs-words.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: You heare ſir, ſhe can talke, God be thanked.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: I would I heard it not ſir.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: I finde that all the pity beſtowd upon this woman,
Makes but an Anagram of an ill wife,
For ſhe was never vertuous.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Youl let me in I hope, for all this jeſting.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Hope ſtill Sir.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: You will come down I am ſure.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I am ſure I will not.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Ile fetch you then.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: The power of the whole County cannot ſir,
Unleſſe we pleaſe to yeild, which yet I thinke
We ſhal not; charge when you pleaſe, you ſhall
Heare quickly from us.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Bleſſe me from a Chicken of thy hatching,
Is this wiving?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Prethee Maria tell me what's the reaſon,
And do it freely, you deale thus ſtrangely with me?
You were not forc'd to marry, your conſent
Went equally with mine, if not before it:
I hope you do not doubt I want that mettle
A man ſhould have to keepe a woman waking;
I would be ſorry to be ſuch a Saint yet:
My perſon, as it is not excellent,
So tis not old, nor lame, nor weak with Phyſick,
But wel enough to pleaſe an honeſt woman,
That keeps her houſe, and loves her husband.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Tis ſo.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: My means and my conditions are no ſhamers
Of him that owes 'em, all the world knows that,
And my friends no reliers on my fortunes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: All this I believe, and none of all theſe parcels
I dare except againſt; nay more, ſo far
I am from making theſe the ends I aime at,
Theſe idle outward things, theſe womens feares,
That were I yet unmarried, free to chooſe
Through all the Tribes of man, i'ld take Petruchio
In's ſhirt, with one ten Groats to pay the Prieſt,
Before the beſt man living, or the ableſt
That ev'r leap'd out of Lancaſhire, and they are right ones.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Why do you play the foole then, and ſtand prating
Out of the window like a broken Miller!

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: If you wil have me credit you Maria,
Come down, and let your love confirme it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Stay there ſir, that bargain's yet to make.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Play ſure wench, the pucks in thine own hand.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Let me die lowſie, it theſe two wenches
Be not brewing knavery to ſtock a Kingdome.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Why this is a Riddle:
I love you, and I love you not.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It is ſo:
And till your own experience do untie it,
This diſtance I muſt keep.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: If you talk more,
I am angry, very angry.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I am glad on't, and I wil talke.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Prethee peace,
Let me not think thou art mad. I tell thee woman,
If thou goeſt forward, I am ſtill Petruchio.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And I am worſe, a woman that can feare
Neither Petruchio Furius, nor his fame,
Nor any thing that tends to our allegeance;
There's a ſhort method for you, now you know me.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: If you can carry't ſo, tis very wel.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: No you ſhall carry it, ſir.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Peace gentle Low-bel.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Uſe no more words, but come down inſtantly,
I charge thee by the duty of a child.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Prethee come Maria, I forgive all.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Stay there; That duty, that you charge me by
(If you conſider truly what you ſay)
Is now another mans, you gave't away
I'th Church, if you remember, to my husband:
So all you can exact now, is no more
But onely a due reverence to your perſon,
Which thus I pay: Your bleſſing, and I am gone
To bed for this night.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: This is monſtrous:
That bleſſing that St. Dunſtan gave the Devil,
If I were neere thee, I would give thee—
Pull thee down by th' noſe.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Saints ſhould not rave, ſir;
A little Rubarb now were excellent.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Then by that duty you owe to me Maria,
Open the doore, and be obedient: I am quiet yet.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I do confeſſe that duty; make your beſt on't.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Why give me leave, I will.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Sir, there's no learning
An old ſtiffe Jade to trot: you know the morall.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yet as I take it ſir, I owe no more
Then you owe back again.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: You wil not Article?
All I owe, preſently, let me but up, ile pay.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Y'are too hot, and ſuch prove Jades at length;
You do confeſſe a duty or reſpect to me from you again:
That's very neere, or full the ſame with mine?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Then by that duty, of reſpect, or what
You pleaſe to have it, goe to bed and leave me,
And trouble me no longer with your fooling;
For know, I am not for you.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Well, what remedy?

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: A fine ſmart Cudgell. Oh that I were neer thee.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: If you had teeth now, what a caſe were we in?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Theſe are the moſt authentique Rebels, next Tyrone, I ever read of.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: A weeke hence, or a fortnight, as you beare you,
And as I finde my will obſerv'd, I may
With interceſſion of ſome friends be brought
May be to kiſſe you; and ſo quarterly
To pay a little rent by compoſition,
You underſtand me?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Thou Boy, thou.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.p: Well there are more Maides then Maudlin, that's my comfort.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes, and more men then Michael.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: I muſt not to bed with this ſtomach, and no meat Lady.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Feed where you will, ſo it be ſound, and wholſome,
Elſe live at livery, for i'le none with you.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: You had beſt back one of the dairy maids, they'l carry.
But take heed to your girthes, you'l get a bruiſe elſe.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Now if thou would'ſt come down, and tender me:
All the delights due to a marriage bed,
Studdy ſuch kiſſes as would melt a man,
And turne thy ſelfe into a thouſand figures,
To adde new flames unto me, I would ſtand
Thus heavy, thus regardleſſe, thus deſpiſing
Thee, and thy beſt allurings: all thy beauty
That's laid upon your bodies, mark me well,
For without doubt your mind's are miſerable,
You have no maskes for them: all this rare beauty,
Lay but the Painter, and the ſilke worme by,
The Doctor with his dyets, and the Taylor,
And you appeare like flead Cats, not ſo handſome.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And we appeare like her that ſent us hither,
That onely excellent and beauteous nature;
Truly our ſelves, for men to wonder at,
But too divine to handle; we are Gold,
In our own natures pure; but, when we ſuffer
The husbands ſtamp upon us then alayes,
And baſ ones of you, men are mingled with us,
And make us bluſh like Copper.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Then, and never
Till then are women to be ſpoken of,
For till that time you have no ſoules I take it:
Good night: come Gentlemen; i'le faſt for this night,
But by this hand—well: I ſhall come up yet?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Noe.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: There will I watch thee like a wither'd Jewry,
Thou ſhalt neither have meat, fire, nor Candle,
Nor any thing that's eaſie: doe you rebell ſo ſoone?
Yet take mercy.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Put up your Pipes; to bed ſir; i'le aſſure you
A moneths ſeige will not ſhake us.

sp.speaker: Moro.
sp.l: Well ſaid Colonell.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: To bed to bed Petruchio: good night Gentlemen,
You'l make my Father ſicke with ſitting up:
Here you ſhall finde us any time theſe ten dayes,
Unleſſe we may march off with our contentment.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Ile hang firſt.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And i'le quarter if I doe not,
Ile make you know, and feare a wife Petruchio,
There my cauſe lies.
You have been famous for a woman tamer,
And beare the fear'd-name of a brave wife-breaker:
A woman now ſhall take thoſe honours off,
And tame you; nay, never look ſo bigge, ſhe ſhall beleeve me,
And I am ſhe: what thinke ye; good night to all,
Ye ſhall finde Centines.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: If ye dare ſally. Exeunt above.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.p: The devill's in 'em, ev'n the very devill, the downe right devill.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.p: Ile devill 'em: by theſe ten bones I will: i'le bring it to the old Proverb no ſport no pie: — taken down i'th top of all my ſpeed; this is fine danc|ing: Gentlemen, ſtick to me. You ſee our Freehold's touch'd, and by this light, we will beleaguer'em, and either ſtarve 'em out, or make 'em recreant.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Ile ſee all paſſages ſtopt, but thoſe about 'em:
If the good women of the Towne dare ſuccour 'em,
We ſhall have warres indeed.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Ile ſtand perdue uppn 'em.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: My regiment ſhall lye before.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: I think ſo, 'tis grown too old to ſtand.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Let's in, and each provide his tackle,
We'l fire'em out, or make'em take their pardons,
Heare what I ſay, on their bare knees —
Am I Petruchio, fear'd, and ſpoken of,
And on my wedding night am I thus jaded? Exe. Omnes.

div.head: Scaena quarta.
div.stage: Enter Rowland, and Pedro, at ſeverall doores.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Now Pedro?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Very buſie Maſter Rowland.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: What haſte man?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I beſeech you pardon me,
I am not mine own man.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Thou art not mad?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: No; but beleeve me, as haſty—

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: The cauſe good Pedro?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: There be a thouſand ſir; you are not married?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Not yet.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Keepe your ſelfe quiet then.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: You'l finde a Fiddle
That never will be tun'd elſe: from all women— Exit. Enter Iaques,

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: What ailes the fellow tro? Iaques?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Your friend ſir.
But very full of buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Nothing but buſineſſe?
Prethee the reaſon, is there any dying?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: I would there were ſir.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: But thy buſineſſe?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Ile tell you in a word,
I am ſent to lay
An impoſition upon Sowſe and Puddings,
Paſties, and Penny Cuſtards, that the women
May not releeve you Rebels: Fare ye well ſir.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: How does my Miſtreſſe?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Like a reſty jade.
She's ſpoil'd for riding. Exit Iaques.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: What a devill ayle they? Enter Sophocles.
Cuſtards, and penney Paſties, Fooles and Fiddles,
What's this to'th purpoſe? O well met.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Now Rowland.
I cannot ſtay to talk long.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: What's the matter?
Here's ſtirring, but to what end? whether goe you?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: To view the works.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: What workes?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: The womens Trenches.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Trenches? are ſuch to ſee?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: I doe not jeſt ſir.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: I cannot underſtand you.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Doe not you heare
In what a ſtate of quarrell the new Bride
Stands with her husband?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Let him ſtand with her, and there's an end.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: It ſhould be, but by'r Lady
She holds him out at Pikes end, and defies him,
And now is fortifide; ſuch a Regiment of Rutters
Never defied men braver: I am ſent
To view their preparation.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: This is newes
Stranger then Armes in the ayre, you ſaw not
My gentle Miſtreſſe?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Yes, and meditating
Upon ſome ſecret buſineſſe, when ſhe had found it
She leapt for joy, and laugh'd, and ſtraight retir'd
To ſhun Moroſo.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: This maybe for me.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Will you along?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Farewell. Exit Sophocles.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Farewell ſir.
What ſhould her muſing meane, and what her joy in't,
If not for my advantage? ſtay ye; may not Enter Livia at one doore, and Moroſo at another hark|ning.
That Bob-taile Jade Moroſo, with his Gold,
His gew-gaudes, and the hope ſhe has to ſend him
Quickly to duſt, excite this? here ſhe comes,
And yonder walkes the Stallion to diſcover:
Yet i'le ſalute her: ſave you beauteous miſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Livi.
sp.l: The Fox is kennell'd for me: ſave you ſir.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Why doe you looke ſo ſtrange?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: I uſe to looke ſir
Without examination.

sp.speaker: Moro.
sp.l: Twenty Spur-Royals for that word.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Belike then
The object diſcontents you?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Yes it does.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Is't come to this? you know me, doe you not?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Yes as I may know many by repentance.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Why doe you breake your faith?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Ile tell you that too,
You are under age, and no band holds upon you.

sp.speaker: Moro.
sp.l: Excellent wench.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Sue out your underſtanding,
And get more haire, to cover your bare knuckle
(For Boyes were made for nothing, but dry kiſſes,)
And if you can, more manners.

sp.speaker: Moro.
sp.l: Better ſtill.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: And then if I want Spaniſh gloves, or ſtockings,
A ten-pound waſte-coate, or a Nag to hunt on,
It may be I ſhall grace you to accept 'em.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Farewell, and when I credit women more,
May I to Smith-field, and there buy a Jade,
(And know him to be ſo) that breakes my neck.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Becauſe I have knowne you, Ile be thus kinde to you;
Farewell, and be a man, and i'le provide you,
Becauſe I ſee y'are deſperate, ſome ſtai'd Chamber-maid
That may relieve your youth, with wholeſome doctrin.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: She's mine from all the world: ha wench?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.p: Ha Chicken? — gives him a box o'th eare and Ex.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: How's this? I do not love theſe favours: ſave you.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: The devill take thee— wrings him byth' noſe.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: There's a love token for you: thank me now.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Ile thinke on ſome of ye, and if I live,
My noſe alone ſhall not be plaid withall. Exit.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: A Box o'th eare doe you ſay?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Yes ſure a ſound one,
Beſide my noſe blown to my hand; if Cupid
Shoot Arrows of that waight, i'le ſweare devoutly,
Has ſude his liverie, and no more a Boy.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: You gave her ſome ill language?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Not a word,

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Or might be you weare fumbling?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Would I had ſir.
I had been a forehand then; but to be baffel'd,
And have no feeling of the cauſe—

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Be patient,
I have a medicine clapt to her back will cure her.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: No ſure it muſt be afore ſir.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: O' my Conſcience,
When I got theſe two wenches (who till now
Ne'r ſhew'd their riding) I was drunck with Baſtard,
Whoſe nature is to forme things like it ſelfe
Heady, and monſtrous: did ſhe ſlight him too?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: That's all my comfort: a meere Hobby-horſe
She made childe Rowland: ſ'foot ſhe would not know him,
Not give him a free look, not reckon him
Among her thoughts, which I held more then wonder,
I having ſeene her within's three dayes kiſſe him
With ſuch an appetite as though ſhe would eat him.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: There is ſome trick in this: how did he take it?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Ready to cry; he ran away.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: I feare her.
And yet I tell you, ever to my anger,
She is as tame as Innocency; it may be
This blow was but a favour.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Ile be ſworne
'Twas well tye'd on then.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Goe too, pray forget it,
I have beſpoke a Prieſt: and within's two houres
Ile have ye married; will that pleaſe you?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Ile ſee it done my ſelfe, and give the Lady
Such a ſound exhortation for this knavery
Ile warrant you, ſhall make her ſmell this Moneth on't,

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Nay good ſir, be not violent.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Neither—

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: It may be
Out of her earneſt love, there grew a longing
(As you know women have ſuch toyes) in kindneſſe,
To give me a box o'th eare or ſo.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: It may be.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: I reckon for the beſt ſtill: this night then
I ſhall enjoy her.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: You ſhall hanſell her.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Old as I am, i'le give her one blow for't
Shall make her groane this twelve-moneth.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Where's your joynture?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: I have a joynture for her.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Have your Councell
Peruſ'd it yet?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: No Councell, but the night, and your ſweet daughter
Shall ere peruſe that Joynture.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Very well ſir.

sp.speaker: Moro.
sp.l: Ile no demurrers on't nor no rejoynders.
The other's ready ſeal'd.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Come then lets' comfort
My Son Petruchio, he's like little Children
That looſe their Bables, crying ripe.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Pray tell me,
Is this ſtern woman ſtill upon the flaunt
Of bold defiance?

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Still, and ſtill ſhe ſhall be
Till ſhe be ſtarv'd out: you ſhall ſee ſuch juſtice,
That women ſhall be glad after this tempeſt
To tye their husbands ſhooes, and walke their horſes;
That were a merry world: doe you heare the rumour,
They ſay the women are in Inſurrection,
And meane to make a —

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: They'l ſooner
Draw upon walls as we doe: Let 'em, let 'em,
We'l ſhip 'em out in Cuck-ſtooles, there they'l ſaile
As brave Columbus did, till they diſcover
The happy Iſlands of obedience.
We ſtay too long, Come.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Now Saint George be with us. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Now if I can but get in hanſomely,
Father I ſhall deceive you, and this night
For all your private plotting, i'le no wedlock;
I have ſhifted ſaile, and finde my Siſters ſafety
A ſure retirement; pray to heaven that Rowland
Do not beleeve too farre, what I ſaid to him,
For y'on old Foxcaſe forc'd me, that's my feare.
Stay, let me ſee, this quarter fierce Petruchio
Keepes with his Myrmidons: I muſt be ſuddaine,
If he ſeize on me, I can looke for nothing
But Marſhall Law; to this place have I ſcap'd him;
Above there. Enter Maria, and Byancha above.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: A Friend.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Who are you?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Looke out and know.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Alas poore wench who ſent thee,
What weake foole made thy tongue his Orator?
I know you come to parly.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Y'are deceiv'd,
Urg'd by the goodnes of your cauſe I come
To doe as you doe.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Y'ar too weake, too fooliſh,
To cheat us with your ſmoothneſſe: doe not we know
Thou haſt been kept up tame?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Beleeve me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No, prethee good Livia
Utter thy Eloquence ſomewhere elſe.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Good Coſen
Put up your Pipes; we are not for your palat,
Alas we know who ſent you.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: O' my word —

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Stay there; you muſt not thinke your word,
Or by your Maydenhead, or ſuch Sonday oathes
Sworne after Even-Song, can inveigle us
To looſe our hand-faſt: did their wiſdomes thinke
That ſent you hither, we would be ſo fooliſh,
To entertaine our gentle Siſter Sinon,
And give her credit, while the woodden Jade
Petruchio ſtole upon us: no good Siſter,
Goe home, and tell the merry Greekes that ſent you,
I●ium ſhall burn, and I, as did Aeneas,
will on my back, ſpite of the Myrmidons,
Carry this warlike Lady, and through Seas
Unknown, and unbeleev'd, ſeek out a Land,
Where like a race of noble Amazons,
We'le root our ſelves and to our endleſſe glory
Live, and deſpiſe baſe men.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Ile ſecond ye.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: How long have you been thus?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: That's all one Coſen.
I ſtand for freedome now.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Take heed of lying;
For by this light, if we doe credit you,
And finde you tripping, his infliction
That kill'd the Prince of Orenge, will be ſport
To what we purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Let me feele the heavieſt.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Swear by thy Sweet-heart Rowland (for by your mayden-head,
I feare 'twill be too late to ſwear) you meane
Nothing but faire and ſafe, and honourable
To us, and to your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: I ſweare.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Stay yet,
Sweare as you hate Moroſo, that's the ſureſt,
And as you have a certaine feare to finde him
Worſe then a poore dride Jack, full of more Aches
Then Autumne has; more knavery, and uſury,
And foolery, and brokery, then doggs-ditch:
As you doe conſtantly beleeve he's nothing
But an old empty bagge with a grey beard,
And that beard ſuch a Bob-taile, that it lookes
Worſe then a Mares taile eaten off with Fillyes:
As you acknowledge, that young hanſome wench
That lyes by ſuch a Bilbo blade, that bends
With ev'ry paſſe he makes to'th hilts, moſt miſ●rable,
A dry nurſe to his Coughes, a fewterer
To ſuch a naſty fellow, a rob'd thing
Of all delights youth lookes for: and to end,
One caſt away on courſe beef, born to bruſh
That everlaſting Caſſock that has worne
As many Servants out, as the Northeaſt paſſage
Has conſum'd Saylors: if you ſweare this, and truly
Without the reſervation of a gowne
Or any meritorious Petticoate,
'Tis like we ſhall beleeve you.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: I doe ſweare it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Stay yet a little; came this wholeſome motion
(Deale truly Siſter) from your own opinion,
Or ſome ſuggeſtion of the Foe?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Nev'r feare me,
For by that little faith I have in husbands,
And the great zeale I beare your cauſe, I come
Full of that liberty, you ſtand for, Siſter.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: If we beleeve, and you prove recreant Livia,
Think what a maym you give the noble Cauſe
We now ſtand up for: Thinke what women ſhall
An hundred yeare hence ſpeak thee, when examples
Are look'd for, and ſo great ones, whoſe relations
Spoke as we doe th'em wench, ſhall make new cuſtoms.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: If you be falſe, repent, goe home, and pray,
And to the ſerious women of the City
Confeſſe your ſelfe; bring not a ſinne ſo heynous
To load thy ſoule, to this place: mark me Livia,
If thou bee it double, and betray'ſt our honours,
And we fail in our purpoſe: get thee where
There is no women living, nor no hope
There ever ſhall be.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: If a Mothers daughter,
That ever heard the name of ſtubborn husband
Found thee, and know thy ſinne.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Nay, if old age,
One that has worne away the name of woman,
And no more left to know her by, but railing,
No teeth, nor eyes nor legges, but woodden ones
Come but i'th wind-ward of thee, forſure ſhe'l ſmell thee
Thou'lt be ſo ranck, ſhe'l ride thee like a night-mare,
And ſay her Prayers back-ward to undoe thee,
She'l curſe thy meat and drink, and when thou marrieſt,
Clap a ſound ſpell for ever on thy pleaſures.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Children of five yeare old, like little Fayries
Will pinch thee into motley, all that ever
Shall live, and heare of thee, I meane all women;
Will (like ſo many furies) ſhake their Keyes,
And toſſe their flaming diſtaffes o're their heads,
Crying Revenge: take heed, 'tis hideous:
Oh 'tis a fearefull office, if thou had'ſt
(Though thou bee'ſt perfect now) when thou cam'ſt, hither,
A falſe Imagination, get thee gone,
And as my learned Cozen ſaid repent,
This place is ſought by ſoundneſſe.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: So I ſeeke it,
Or let me be a moſt deſpis'd example.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I doe beleeve thee, be thou worthy of it.
You come not empty?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: No, Here's Cakes, and cold meat,
And tripe of proofe: behold here's wine, and beere,
Be ſuddaine, I ſhall be ſurpriz'd elſe.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Meet at the low Parlor doore, there lyes a cloſe way:
What fond obedience you have living in you,
Or duty to a man, before you enter,
Fling it away, 'twill but defile our Offrings.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Be wary as you come,

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: I warrant ye. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: 1 Mai.
sp.l: How goes your buſineſſe Girles?
A foot, and faire.
If fortune favour us: away to your ſtrength
The Country Forces are ariv'd, be gone.
We are diſcover'd elſe.
Arme? and be valiant.
Think of our cauſe.
Our Juſtice.
'Tis ſufficient. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena quarta.
div.stage: Enter Rowland and Tranio at ſeverall doores.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Now Rowland?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: How yoe you?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: How do'ſt thou man,
Thou look'ſt ill:

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Yes, pray can you tell me Tranio,
Who knew the devill firſt?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: A woman.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Thou haſt heard I am ſure of Eſculapius.
So were they not well acquainted?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: May be ſo,
For they had certaine Dialogues together.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: He ſold her fruit, I take it?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Yes, and Cheeſe
That choak'd all mankinde after.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Canſt thou tell me
Whether that woman ever had a faith
After ſhe had eaten?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: That's a Schoole queſtion

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: No
'Tis no queſtion, for beleeve me Tranio,
That cold fruit after eating bread naught in her
But windy promiſes, and chollick vowes
That broke out both wayes.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Thou ha'ſt heard I am ſure
Of Eſculapius, a farre famed Surgeon,
One that could ſet together quarter'd Traytors,
And make 'em honeſt men.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: How do'ſt thou Rowland?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Let him but take, (if he dare doe a cure
Shall get him fame indeed) a faithleſſe woman,
There will be credit for him, that will ſpeake him,
A broken woman Tranio, a baſe woman,
And if he can cure ſuch a rack of honour
Let him come here, and practiſe.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Now for honours ſake
Why what ayl'ſt thou Rowland?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: I am ridden Tranio.
And Spur-gald to the life of patience
(Heaven keepe my wits together) by a thing
Our worſt thoughts are too noble for, a woman.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Your Miſtreſſe has a little frown'd it may be?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: She was my Miſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Is ſhe not?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: No Tranio.
She has done me ſuch diſgrace, ſo ſpitefully,
So like a woman bent to my undoing,
That henceforth a good horſe ſhall be my Miſtreſſe,
A good Sword, or a Booke: and if you ſee her,
Tell her I doe beſeech you, even for love ſake.—

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I will Rowland.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: She may ſooner
Count the good I have thought her,
Our old love and our friend-ſhip,
Shed one true teare, meane one houre conſtantly,
Be old, and honeſt, married, and a maide,
Then make me ſee her more, or more beleeve her:
And now I have met a Meſſenger, farewell ſir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Alas poore Rowland, I will doe it for thee:
This is that dogge Moroſo, but I hope
To ſee him cold i'th mouth firſt 'er he enjoy her:
Ile watch this young man, deſperate thoughts may ſeize him,
And if my purſe, or councell can, i'le eaſe him. Exit

div.head: Scaena quinta.
div.stage: Enter Petruchio, Petronius, Moroſo, and Sophocles.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: For looke you Gentlemen, ſay that I grant her
Out of my free and liberall love, a pardon,
Which you and all men elſe know ſhe deſerves not,
(Teneatis amici) can all the world leave laughing?

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: I thinke not.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: No by — they cannot;
For pray conſider, have you ever read,
Or heard of, or can any man imagine.
So ſtiffe a Tomb boy, of ſo ſet a ma ice,
And ſuch a brazen reſolution,
As this young Crab-tree? and then anſwer me,
And marke but this too friends, without a cauſe,
Not a foule word comes croſſe her, not a feare,
She juſtly can take hold on, and doe you thinke
I muſt ſleepe out my anger, and endure it,
Sow pillows to her eaſe, and lull her miſchiefe?
Give me a Spindle firſt: no, no my Maſters,
Were ſhe as faire as Nell a Greece, and houſe-wife,
As good as the wife Saylors wife, and young ſtill,
Never above fifteene; and theſe tricks to it,
She ſhould ride the wild Mare once a week, ſhe ſhould.
(Believe me friends ſhe ſhould) I would tabor her,
Till all the Legions that are crept into her,
Flew out with fire i'th tailes.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Me thinks you erre now,
For to me ſeems, a little ſufferance
Were a far ſurer cure.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Yes, I can ſuffer,
Where I ſee promiſes of peace and amendment.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Give her a few conditions.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Ile be hangd firſt.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Give her a crab-tree-cudgell.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: So I will;
And after it a flock-bed for her bones.
And hard egges, till they brace her like a Drum,
She ſhall be pamperd with —
She ſhall not know a ſtoole in ten moneths Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: This muſt not be. Enter Jaques.

sp.speaker: Jaq
sp.l: Arme, arme, out with your weapons,
For all the women in the Kingdom's on ye; Enter Pedro.
They ſwarm like waſpes, and nothing can deſtroy 'em,
But ſtopping of their hive, and ſmothering of 'em.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Stand to your guard ſir, all the devils extant
Are broke upon us, like a cloud of thunder;
There are more women, marching hitherward,
In reſcue of my Miſtris, th●n ere turn'd taile
At Sturbridge Faire; and I believe, as fiery.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: The forlorn-hope's led by a Tanners wife,
I know her by her hide; a deſperate woman:
She flead her husband in her youth, and made
Raynes of his hide to ride the Pariſh. Take 'em all together,
They are a genealogy of Jennets, gotten
And born thus, by the boyſterous breath of husbands;
They ſerve ſure, and are ſwift to catch occaſion,
(I meane their foes, or husbands) by the fore-locks,
And there they hang like favours; cry they can,
But more for Noble ſpight, then feare: and crying
Like the old Gyants that were foes to Heaven,
They heave ye ſtoole on ſtoole, and fling main Potlids
Like maſſie rocks, dart ladles, toſſing Irons,
And tongs like Thunderbolts, till overlayd,
They fall beneath the waight; yet ſtill aſpiring
At thoſe Emperious Godſheads, that would tame 'em.
There's nere a one of theſe, the worſt and weakeſt,
(Chooſe where you will) but dare attempt the rayſing
Againſt the ſoveraigne peace of Puritans,
A May-pole, and a Morris, maugre mainly
Their zeale, and Dudgeon-daggers: and yet more,
Dares plant a ſtand of battring Ale againſt 'em,
And drinke 'em out o'th Pariſh

sp.speaker: Saph.
sp.p: Lo you fierce Petruchio, this comes of your impatience.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: There's one brought in the Beares againſt the Canons
Of the Town, made it good, and fought 'em.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Another, to her everlaſting fame, erected
Two Ale-houſes of eaſe: the quarter-ſeſſions
Running againſt her roundly; in which buſineſſe
Two of the diſannullers loſt their night-caps:
A third ſtood excommunicate by the cudgell.
The Cunſtable, to her eternall glory,
Drunke hard, and was converted, and ſhe victor.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Then are they victualed with pies and puddings,
(The trappings of good ſtomacks) noble Ale
the true defendor, Sawſages, and ſmoak'd ones,
If need be, ſuch as ſerve for Pikes; and Porke,
(Better the Jewes never hated:) here and there
A bottle of Metheglin, a ſtout Bricaine
That wil ſtand to 'em, what elſe they want, they war for.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Come to councell,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Now you muſt grant conditions or the Kingdom
Will have no other talke but this.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Away then, and let's adviſe the beſt.

sp.speaker: Soph:
sp.l: Why doe you tremble?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Have I liv'd thus long to be knockt o'th head,
With halfe a waſhing beetle? pray be wiſe ſir.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Come, ſomething Ile doe; but what it is I know not.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: To councel then, and let's avoyd their follies.
Guard all the doors, or we ſhal not have a cloke left. Exe

div.stage: Enter three mayds, at ſeverall doors.

sp.l: How goes the buſineſſe, girles?
A foot, and faire.
If fortune favour us: away to your ſtrength,
The Country forces are ariv'd; be gon we are diſcovered elſe.
Arme, and be valiant.
Think of our cauſe.
Our iuſtice.
Tis ſufficient. Exeunt

div.head: Scena tertia.
div.stage: Enter Petronius, Petruchio, Moroſo, Sophocles, and Tranio.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: I am indifferent, though I muſt confeſſe,
I had rather ſee her carted.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: No more of that ſir.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Are ye reſolv'd to give her fair conditions?
Twill be the ſafeſt way.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: I am diſtracted,
Would I had run my head into a halter
When I firſt woo'd her: if I offer peace,
She'l urge her own conditions, that's the devil.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Why ſay ſhe do?

sp.speaker: Petru:
sp.l: Say, I am made an Aſſe, then;
I know her aime: may I with reputation
(Anſwer me this) with ſafety of mine honour,
(After the mighty mannage of my firſt wife,
Which was indeed a fury to this Filly,
After my twelve ſtrong labours to reclaime her,
Which would have made Don Hercules horn mad,
And hid him in his hide) ſuffer this Sicely,
Ere ſhe have warm'd my ſheets, ere grappel'd with me,
This Pinck, this painted Foyſt, this Cockle-boat,
To hang her Fights out, and defie me friends,
A wel known man of war? if this be equal,
And I may ſuffer, ſay, and I have done?

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: I do not think you may.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: You'l make it worſe ſir.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Pray heare me good Petruchio: but ev'n now,
You were contented to give all conditions,
To try how far ſhe would carry: Tis a folly,
(And you wil find it ſo) to clap the curb on,
Er you be ſure it proves a naturall wildneſſe,
And not a forc'd. Give her conditions,
For on my life this tricke is put into her.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: I ſhould believe ſo too.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: And not her own.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: You'l finde it ſo.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Then if ſhe flownder with you,
Clap ſpurs on, and in this you'l deale with temperance,
Avoyd the hurry of the world.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: And looſe Muſick above.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: No honour on my life, ſir.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: I wil do it.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: It ſeems they are very merry. Enter Jaques.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Why God hold it.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Now Jaques?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: They are i'th flaunt, ſir.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Yes we heare 'em.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: They have got a ſtick of Fiddles, and they firke it
In wondrous waies, the two grand Capitanos,
(They brought the Auxiliary Regiments)
Daunce with their coats tuckt up to their bare breeches,
And bid them kiſſe 'em, that's the burden;
They have got Metheglin, and audacious Ale,
And talke like Tyrants.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: How knoweſt thou?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: I peep't in Song!
At a looſe Lansket.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Harke.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: A Song, pray ſilence. All the women above.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: They look out.

sp.speaker: Petru
sp.l: Good ev'n Ladies.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Good you good ev'n ſir.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: How have you ſlept to night?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Exceeding well ſir.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Did you not wiſh me with you?

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.l: No, believe me,
I never thought upon you.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Is that he?

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Sir?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: She has drunk hard, mark her hood.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: You are —

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Learuedly drunk, Ile hang elſe: let her utter.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: And I muſt tell you, viva voce friend,
A very fooliſh fellow.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: There's an Ale figure.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: I thank you Suſan Brotes.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.l: Forward ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: You have eſpouſed here a hearty woman,
A comely, and couragious.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Wel I have ſo.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: And to the comfort of diſtreſſed damſels,
Weomen out-worn in wedlock, and ſuch veſſels,
This woman has defied you.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: It ſhould ſeem ſo.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: And why?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Yes, can you tell?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: For thirteen cauſes.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Pray by your patience Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.l: Forward ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Do you mean to treat of all theſe?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.l: Who ſhall let her?

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Doe you heare, Velvet-hood, we come not now
To heare your doctrine.

sp.speaker: Cunt.
sp.l: For the firſt, I take it,
It doth divide it ſelfe into ſeven branches.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Harke you good Maria,
Have you got a Catechiſer here?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Good zeale.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Good three pil'd predication, will you peace,
And heare the cauſe we come for?

sp.speaker: Cunt.
sp.l: Yes Bob-tailes
We know the cauſe you come for, here's the cauſe,
But never hope to carry her, never dream
Or flatter your opinions with a thought
Of baſe repentance in her.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.l: Give me ſack,
By this, and next ſtrong Ale.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Sweare forward ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.l: By all that's cordiall, in this place we'l bury
Our bones, fames, tongues, our triumphs; and then all
That ever yet was chronicl'd of woman;
But this brave wench, this excellent deſpiſer,
This bane of dull obedience, ſhall inherit
His liberall wil, and march off with conditions
Noble, and worth her ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: She ſhall Tom Tilers,
And brave ones too; My hood ſhal make a hearſe-cloth,
And I lie under it, like Jone o Gaunt,
Ere I goe leſſe, my Diſtaffe ſtucke up by me,
For the eternall Trophce of my conqueſts;
And loud fame at my head, with two main Bottles,
Shall fill to all the world the glorious fall
Of old Don Gillian.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.l: Yet a little further,
We have taken Armes in reſcue of this Lady;
Moſt juſt and Noble: if ye beat us off
Without conditions, and we recant,
Uſe us as we deſerve; and firſt degrade us
Of all our ancient chambring: next that
The Symbols of our ſecrecy, ſilke Stockings,
Hew of our heeles; our petticotes of Armes
Teare of our bodies, and our Bodkins breake
Over our coward heads.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: And ever after
To make the tainture moſt notorious,
At all our Creſts, videlicet our Plackets.
Let Laces hang, and we returne againe
Into our former titles, Dayry maids.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: No more wars: puiſſant Ladies, ſhew conditions,
And freely I accept 'em.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Call in Livia;
She's in the treaty too. Enter Livia above.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: How, Livia?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Heare you that ſir?
There's the conditions for ye, pray peruſe 'em.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Yes, there ſhe is: t'had been no right rebellion,
Had ſhe held off; what think you man?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Nay nothing.
I have enough o'th proſpect: o'my conſcience,
The worlds end, and the goodneſſe of a woman
Will come together.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Are you there ſweet Lady?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Cry you mercy ſir, I ſaw you not: your bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.p: Yes when I bleſſe a jade, that ſtumbles with me. How are the Articles?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: This is for you ſir;
And I ſhal think upon't.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: You have us'd me finely.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: There's no other uſe of thee now extant,
But to be hung up; caſſock, cap, and all,
For ſome ſtrange monſter at Apothecaries.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: I heare you whore.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: It muſt be his then ſir,
For need wil then compell me.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.l: Bleſſing on thee.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: He wil undoe me in meere pans of Coles
To make him luſtie.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: There's no talking to 'eni;
How are they ſir?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: As I expected: Liberty and clothes, Reads.
When, and in what way ſhe wil: continuall moneys,
Company, and all the houſe at her diſpoſe;
No tongue to ſay, why is this? or whether wil it;
New Coaches, and ſome buildings, ſhe appoints here,
Hangings, and hunting-horſes: and for Plate
And Jewels for her private uſe, I take it,
Two twouſand pound in preſent: then for Muſick,
And women to read French;

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: This muſt not be.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: And at the latter end a clauſe put in,
That Livia ſhal by no man be importun'd.
This whole moneth yet, to marry.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: This is monſtrous.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: This ſhall be done, Ile humor her awhile:
If nothing but repentance, and undoing
Can win her love, Ile make a ſhift for one.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: When ye are once a bed, all theſe conditions
Lie under your own ſeale.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Do yo like 'em?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Yes.
And by that faith I gave you fore the Prieſt
Ile ratifie 'em.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Stay, what pledges?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No, Ile take that oath;
But have a care you keep it.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.l: Tis not now
As when Andrea liv'd.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: If you do juggle,
Or alter but a Letter or theſe Articles
We have ſet down, the ſelf-ſame perſecution.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Miſtruſt him not.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: By all my honeſty —

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Enough I yield.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: What's this
Inſerted here?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: That the two valiant women that command here
Shall have a Supper made em, and a large one,
And liberall entertainment without grudging,
And pay for all their Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: That ſhall be too;
And if a tun of Wine wil ſerve to pay 'em,
They ſhall have juſtice: I ordaine ye all
Pay-maſters, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Then we ſhall have ſport boyes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: We'l meet you in the Parlour.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Ne'r looke ſad ſir, for I will doe it.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: There's no danger in't.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: For Livia's Article, you ſhall obſerve it,
I have tyde my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: I wil.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Along then: now
Either I break, or this ſtiffe plant muſt bow. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Come, you ſhall take my counſell.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: I ſhall hang firſt.
Ile no more love, that's certaine, tis a bane,
(Next that they poyſon Rats with) the moſt mortall:
No, I thank Heaven, I have got my ſleep again,
And now begin to write ſence; I can walk ye
A long howre in my chamber like a man,
And think of ſomething that may better me;
Some ſerious point of Learning, or my ſtate;
No more ay-mees, and miſeries Tranio
Come neer my brain. Ile tell thee, had the devil
But any eſſence in him of a man,
And could be brought to love, and love a woman,
Twould make his head ake worſer then his hornes doe;
And make him with a fire he never felt yet,
Would make him dance. I tell thee there is nothing
(It may be thy caſe Tranio, therefore heare me:)
Under the Sun (reckon the maſſe of follies
Crept into th'world with man) ſo deſperate,
So madde, ſo ſenceleſſe, poor and baſe, ſo wretched,
Roguy, and ſcurvy.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: VVhether wilt thou Rowland?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: As tis to be in love.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: And why for vertues ſake?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: And why for vertues ſake? do'ſt thou not conceive me?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: No by my troth.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Pray then, and hartely
For fear thou fall into 't: I'le tell thee why too,
(For I have hope to ſave thee) when thou loveſt,
And firſt beginſt to worſhip the gilt calfe,
Imprimis, thou haſt loſt thy gentry,
And like a prentice flung away thy freedom.
Forthwith thou art a ſlave.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: That's a new Doctrine.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Next thou art no more man.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: VVhat then?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: A Fryppery;
Nothing but brayded haire, and penny riband,
Glove, garter, ring, roſe, or at beſt a ſwabber,
If thou canſt love ſo neer to keep thy making,
Yet thou wilt looſe thy language.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: VVhy.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: O Tranio,
Thoſe things in love, ne'r talke as we do,

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: No?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: No without doubt, they ſigh and ſhake the head,
And ſometimes whiſtle dolefully.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: No tongue?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Yes Tranio, but no truth in't, nor no reaſon,
And when they cant (for tis a kind of canting)
Ye ſhall hear, if you reach to underſtand 'em
(Which you muſt be a foole firſt, or you cannot)
Such gibbriſh; ſuch believe me, I proteſt Sweet,
And oh deer Heavens, in which ſuch conſtellations
Raigne at the births of lovers, this is too well,
And daigne me Lady, daigne me I beſeech ye
You poor unworthy lump, and then ſhe licks him

sp.speaker: Tra
sp.l: A — on't, this is nothing.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Thun ha'ſt hit it:
Then talks ſhe ten times worſe, and wryes and wriggles,
As though ſhe had the itch (and ſo it may be.)

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Why thou art grown a ſtrange diſcoverer.

sp.speaker: Row
sp.l: Of mine own follies Tranio.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: VVilt thou Rowland,
Certaine ne'r love again?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: I think ſo, certain,
And if I be not dead drunk, I ſhall keep it.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Tell me but this; what do'ſt thou think of women?

sp.speaker: Row
sp.l: VVhy as I think of fiddles, they delight me,
Till their ſtrings break.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: VVhat ſtrings?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Their modeſties,
Faithes, vowes and maidenheads, for they are like Kits
They have but foure ſtrings to 'em.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: VVhat wilt thou
Give me for ten pound now, when thou next loveſt,
And the ſame woman ſtill?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Give me the money;
A hundred, and my Bond for't.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: But pray hear me.
I'le work all meanes I can to reconcile ye:

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Do, do, give me the money.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: There.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: VVork Tranio.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: You ſhall go ſometimes where ſhe is.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Yes ſtraight.
This is the firſt good I ere got by woman.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: You would think it ſtrange now, if an other beauty
As good as hers, ſay better.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Well.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Conceive me,
This is no point o'th wager.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: That's all one.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Love you as much, or more, then ſhe now hates you.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Tis a good hearing, let 'em love: ten pound more,
I never love that woman.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: There it is;
And ſo an hundred, if you loſe.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Tis done;
Have you an other to put in?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: No, no ſir.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: I am very ſorry: now will I erect
A new Game and go hate for th' bell, I am ſure
I am in excellent caſe to win.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I muſt have leave.
To tell you, and tell truth too, what ſhe is,
And how ſhee ſuffers for you.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Ten pound more,
I never believe you.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: No ſir, I am ſtinted.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Well, take your beſt way then.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Let's walk, I am glad
Your ſullen feavor's off.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Shal't ſee me Tranio
A monſtrous merry man now: let's to the Wedding,
And as we go, tell me the generall hurry
Of theſe madde wenches, and their workes.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: And do thy worſt.

sp.speaker: Tra
sp.l: Something i'le do.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Do Tranio. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: A paire of ſtocks beſtride 'em, are they gone?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Yes they are gon; and all the pans i'th Town
Beating before 'em: what ſtrange admonitions
They gave my Maſter, and how fearfully
They threaten'd, if he brok 'em?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: O' my conſcience
Has found his full match now.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: That I believe too.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: How did ſhe entertaine him?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: She lookt on him.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: But ſcurvely.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: With no great affection
That I ſaw: and I heard ſome ſay he kiſſ'd her,
But 'twas upon a treaty, and ſome coppies
Say but her cheek.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Iaques, what wouldſt thou give
For ſuch a wife now?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Full as many prayers
As the moſt zealous Puritane conceives
Out of the meditation of fat veale,
Or birds of prey, cram'd capons, againſt Players,
And to as good a tune too, but againſt her:
That heaven would bleſſe me from her: mark it Pedro,
If this houſe be not turn'd within this fortnight
With the foundation upward, i'le be carted.
My comfort is yet that thoſe Amorities,
That came to back her cauſe, thoſe heathen whores had
their hoods hallowed with ſack.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: How div'liſh drunk they were?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: And how they tumbled, Pedro, didſt thou marke
The Countrey Cavaliero?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Out upon her,
How ſhe turn'd down the Bagget?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: I that ſunke her.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: That drink was wel put to her; what a ſober ſalt
When the chaire fel, ſhe fetchd, with her heels upward?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: And what a piece of Landskip ſhe diſcoverd?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Didſt mark her, when her hood ſel in the Poſſet?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Yes, and there rid, like a Dutch hoy; the Tumbrel,
When ſhe had got her ballaſſe.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: That I ſaw too.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: How faine ſhe would have drawn on Sophocles
To come aboord, and how ſhe ſimperd it—

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I warrant her, ſhe has been a worthy ſtriker.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: I'th heat of Summer there had been ſome hope on't.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Hang her.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: She offerd him a Harry-groat, and belcht out,
Her ſtomack being blown with Ale, ſuch Courtſhip,
Upon my life has givn him twenty ſtooles ſince:
Believe my calculation, theſe old women
When they are tippled, and a little heated
Are like new wheels, theyl roare you all the Town ore
Till they be greaſd.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: The City Cinque●pace
Dame toſſe and Butter, had he Bob too?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Yes,
But ſhe was ſullen drunk, and given to filching,
I ſee her offer at a Spoon; my maſter
I do not like his looke, I feare has faſted
For all this preparation; lets ſteale by him. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Not let you touch her all this night?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Not touch her.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Where was your courage?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Where was her obedience?
Never poore man was ſham'd ſo; never Raſcall
That keeps a ſtud of whores was us'd ſo baſely.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Pray you tell me one thing truly;
Do you love her?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: I would I did not, upon that condition
I paſt thee halfe my Land.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: It may be then,
Her modeſty requir'd a little violence?
Some women love to ſtruggle.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: She had it,
And ſo much that I ſweat for't, ſo I did,
But to no end: I waſht an Ethiope;
She ſwore my force might weary her, but win her
I never could, nor ſhould, till ſhe conſented;
And I might take her body priſoner,
But for her mind or appetite—

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Tis ſtrange;
This woman is the firſt I ever read of,
Refus'd a warranted occaſion,
And ſtanding on ſo faire termes.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: I ſhall quit her.

sp.speaker: Soph,
sp.l: Uſ'd you no more art?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Yes, I ſwore to her,
And by no little ones, if preſently
Without more diſputation on the matter,
She grew not neerer to me, and diſpatcht me
Out of the pain I was, for I was nettl'd,
And willingly, and eagerly, and ſweetly,
I would to her Chamber-maid, and in her hearing
Begin her ſuch a hunteſ-up.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Then ſhe ſtarted?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: No more then I do now; many ſhe anſwered
If I were ſo diſpos'd, ſhe could not help it;
But there was one cal'd Iaques, a poor Butler
One that might well content a ſingle woman.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: And he ſhould tilt her.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: To that ſence, and laſt
She bad me yet theſe ſix nights look for nothing,
Nor ſtrive to purchaſe it, but faire good night,
And ſo good morrow, and a kiſſe or two
To cloſe my ſtomach, for her vow had ſeald it,
And ſhe would keep it conſtant.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Stay ye, ſtay ye,
Was ſhe thus when you woo'd her?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Nothing Sophocles,
More keenely eager, I was oft afraid
She had bin light, and eaſy, ſhe would ſhowre
Her kiſſes ſo upon me.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Then I fear
An other ſpoke's i'th wheele.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Now thou haſt found me,
There gnawes my devill, Sophocles, O patience
Preſerve me; that I make her not example
By ſome unworthy way; as fleaing her,
Boyling, or making verjuce, drying her.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: I hear her.

sp.speaker: Petru
sp.l: Mark her then, and ſee the heire
Of ſpight and prodigality, ſhe has ſtudied
A way to begger's both, and by this hand Maria at the dore, and Servant and woman.
She ſhall be if I live a Doxy.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Fy Sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I do not like that dreſſing, tis too poor,
Let me have ſix gold laces, broad and maſſy.
And betwixt ev'ry lace a rich embroydry,
Line the gown through with pluſh, perfum'd, and purffle
All the ſleeves down with pearle.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: What think you Sophocles.
In what point ſtands my ſtate now?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: For thoſe hangings
Let 'em be carried where I gave appointment,
They are too baſe for my uſe, and beſpeak
New pieces of the civill wars of France,
Let 'em be large and lively, and all ſilke work,
The borders gold.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: I marry ſir, this cuts it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: That fourteen yardes of ſatten give my woman,
I do not like the colour, tis too civill:
Ther's too much ſilk i'th lace too; tell the Dutchman
That brought the mares, he muſt with all ſpeed ſend me
An other ſuit of horſes, and by all meanes
Ten calf of Hawkes for 'th River, I much care not
What price they beare, ſo they be ſound, and flying,
For the next winter, I am for the Country;
And mean to take my pleaſure; wher's the horſe man?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: She meanes to ride a great horſe.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: With a ſide ſadle?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Yes, and ſhee'l run a tilt within this twelve-month

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: To morrow Ile begin to learne, but pray ſir
Have a great care he be an eaſy doer,
Twill ſpoyle a Scholler els.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: An eaſy doer,
Did you hear that?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Yes, I ſhal meet her morals
Er it be long I fear not.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O good morrow.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Good morrow Lady, how is't now.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Faith ſickly,
This houſe ſtands in an ill ayre.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Yet more charges?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Subject to rots, and hewms; out on't, tis nothing
But a tild fog.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: What think of the Lodge then?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I like the ſeate, but tis too little, Sophocles
Let me have thy opinion, thou haſt judgement.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Tis very well.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What if I pluck it down,
And built a ſquare upon it, with two courts
Still riſing from the entrance?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: And i'th midſt
A Colledge for yong Scolds.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And to the Southward
Take in a garden of ſome twenty acres,
And caſt it off the Italian faſhion, hanging.

sp.speaker: Petru.
