sp.l: And you could caſt your ſelf ſo too; pray Lady
Will not this coſt much money?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Some five thouſand,
Say ſix: Ile have it battel'd too.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: And gilt; Maria,
This is a fearfull courſe you take pray think on't,
You are a woman now, a wife, and his
That muſt in honeſty, and juſtice look for
Some due obedience from you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: That bare word
Shall coſt you many a pound more, build upon't;
Tell me o● due obedience? what's a husband?
What are we married for, to carry ſumpters?
Are we not one peece with you, and as worthy
Our own intentions, as you yours?

sp.speaker: Petru
sp.l: Pray hear me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Take two ſmall drops of water, equall weigh'd,
Tell me which is the heavieſt, and which ought
Firſt to diſcend in duty?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: You miſtake me;
I urge not ſervice from you, nor obedience
In way of duty, but of love, and oredit;
All I expect is but a noble care
Of what I have brought you, and of what I am,
And what our name may be

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: That's in my making.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Tis true it is ſo.

sp.speaker: Mar
sp.l: Yes it is Petruchio,
For there was never man without our molding,
Without our ſtampe upon him, and our juſtice,
Left any thing three ages after him
Good, and his own.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Good Lady underſtand him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I do too much, ſweet Sophocles, he's one
Of a moſt ſpightfull ſelf condition,
Never at peace with any thing but age,
That has no teeth left to return his anger:
A Bravery dwels in his blood yet, of abuſing
His firſt good wife; he's ſooner fire then powder,
And ſooner miſchief.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: If I be ſo ſodain
Do not you fear me?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No nor yet care for you,
And if it may be lawfull, I defie you:

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Do's this become you now?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It ſhall become me.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Thou diſobedient, weak, vain-glorious woman,
Were I but half ſo wilfull, as thou pightfull,
I ſhould now drag thee to thy duty.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Drag me?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: But I am friends again: take all your pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Now you perceive him Sophocles.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: I love thee
Above thy vanity, thou faithleſſe creature.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Would I had been ſo happy when I married,
But to have met an honeſt man like thee,
For I am ſure thou art good, I know thou art honeſt,
A hanſome hurtleſſe man, a loving man,
Though never a penny with him; and thoſe eyes,
That face, and that true heart; weare this for my ſake,
And when thou thinkſt upon me pity me:
I am caſt away, Exit Mar.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Why how now man?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Pray leave me,
And follow your advices.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: The man's jealous:

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: I ſhall find a time ere it be long, to aske you
One or two fooliſh queſtions.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: I ſhall anſwer
As wel as I am able, when you call me:
If ſhe mean true, tis but a little killing,
And if I do not venture its—
Farewel ſir. Exit Soph.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Pray farewell. Is there no keeping
A wife to one mans uſe? no wintering
Theſe cattell without ſtraying? tis hard dealing,
Very hard dealing, Gentlemen, ſtrange dealing:
Now in the name of madneſſe, what ſtar raign'd,
What dog-ſtar, bull, or bear-ſtar, when I married
This ſecond wife, this whirlwind, that takes all
Within her compaſſe? was I not wel warnd,
(I thought I had, and I believe I know it,)
And beaten to repentance in the daies
Of my firſt doting? had I not wife enough
To turn my love too? did I want vexation,
Or any ſpeciall care to kill my heart?
Had I not ev'ry morning a rare breakfaſt,
Mixt with a learned Lecture of ill language,
Louder then Tom o' Lincoln; and at dinner,
A dyet of the ſame diſh? was there evening
That ere paſt over us, without thou knave,
Or thou whore, for digeſtion? had I ever
A pull at this ſame poor ſport men run mad for,
But like a cur I was faine to ſhew my teeth firſt,
And almoſt worry her? and did Heaven forgive me,
And take this Serpent from me? and am I
Keeping tame devils now again? my heart akes;
Something I muſt do ſpeedily: Ile die,
If I can hanſomely, for that's the way
To make a Raſcall of her; I am ſick,
And Ile go very neer it, but Ile periſh. Exit.

div.head: Scaena Quarta.
div.stage: Enter Livia, Byancha, Tranio, and Rowland.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Then I muſt be content ſir, with my fortune.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: And I with mine.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: I did not think, a look,
Or a poore word or two, could have diſplanted
Such a fix'd conſtancy, and for your end too.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Come, come, I know your courſes: there's no gewgaws,
Your Rings, and Bracelets, and the Purſe you gave me,
The money's ſpent in entertaining you
At Plays, and Cherry-gardens.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: There's your Chain too.
But if you'l give me leave, Ile weare the haire ſtill;
I would yet remember you.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Give him his love wench;
The yong man has imployment for 't.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Fie Rowland.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: You cannot fie me out a hundred pound
With this poore plot: yet, let me nere ſee day more,
If ſomething do not ſtruggle ſtrangely in me.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Young man, let me talk with you.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Wel young woman.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: This was your Miſtris once.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Are ye honeſt?
I ſee you are young, and hanſome.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: I am honeſt.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Why that's wel ſaid: and there's no doubt your judgement
Is good enough, and ſtrong enough to tell you
Who are your foes, and friends: why did you leave her?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: She made a puppy of me.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Be that granted:
She muſt doe ſo ſometimes, and oftentimes;
Love were too ſerious elſe.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: A witty woman.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Had you lov'd me—

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: I would I had.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: And deerly;
And I had lov'd you ſo: you may love worſe ſir,
But that is not materiall.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: I ſhal looſe.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Some time or other for variety
I ſhould have cal'd you foole, or boy, or bid you
Play with the Pages: but have lov'd you ſtil,
Out of all queſtion, and extreamly too;
You are a man made to be loved:

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: This woman
Either abuſes me, or loves me deadly.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Ile tell you one thing, if I were to chooſe
A husband to mine own mind, I ſhould think
One of your mothers making would content me,
For o' my conſcience ſhe makes good ones.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Lady,
Ile leave you to your commendations:
I am in again, The divel take their tongues.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: You ſhall not goe.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: I wil: yet thus far Livia,
Your ſorrow may induce me to forgive you,
But never love again; if I ſtay longer,
I have loſt two hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Good ſir, but thus much—

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Turn if thou beeſt a man.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: But one kiſſe of you;
One parting kiſſe, and I am gone too.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Come,
I ſhall kiſſe fifty pound away at this clap:
We'l have one more, and then farewel.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Farewel.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Wel, go thy waies, thou bearſt a kind heart with thee.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: H'as made a ſtand.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: A noble, brave young fellow,
Worthy a wench indeed.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: I wil: I wil not. Exit Rowland.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: He's gone: but ſhot agen; play you but your part,
And I will keep my promiſe: forty Angels
In fair gold Lady: wipe your eyes: he's yours
If I have any wit.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Ile pay the forfeit.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Come then, lets ſee your ſiſter, how ſhe fares now,
After her skirmiſh: and be ſure, Moroſo
Be kept in good hand; then all's perfect, Livia.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: O Jaques, Jaques, what becomes of us?
Oh my ſweet Maſter.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Run for a Phyſitian,
And a whole peck of Pothecaries, Pedro.
He wil die, didle, didle die: if they come not quickly,
And bring all people that are skilfull
In Lungs and Livers: raiſe the neighbours,
And all the Aquavite-bottles extant;
And, O the Parſon, Pedro; O the Parſon,
A little of his comfort, never ſo little;
Twenty to one you finde him at the Buſh,
There's the beſt Ale.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: I fly. Exit Pedro.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Out with the Trunks, ho:
Why are you idle? Sirha, up to th'Chamber,
And take the hangings down, and ſee the Linnen
Packt up, and ſent away within this halfe houre.
What are the Carts come yet? ſome honeſt body
Help down the cheſts of Plate, and ſome the wardrobe,
Alas we are undone elſe.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Pray forſooth,
And I beſeech ye, tell me, is he dead yet?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No, but is drawing on: out with the Armour.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Then Ile goe ſee him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Thou art undone then fellow: no man that has
Been neere him come neere me.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Why how now Lady, what means this?

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Now daughter, how dos my ſonne?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Save all you can for Heaven ſake.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Be of good comfort ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O my Casket.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: How do's thy husband woman?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Get you gon, if you mean to ſave your lives: the ſickneſſe.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Stand further off, I prethee.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Is i'th houſe ſir,
My husband has it now;
Alas he is infected, and raves extreamly:
Give me ſome counſell friends.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Why lock the doores up,
And ſend him in a woman to attend him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I have beſpoke two women; and the City
Hath ſent a watch by this time: meat nor money
He ſhall not want, nor prayers.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: How long is't
Since it firſt tooke him?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: But within this three houres. Enter Watch.
I am frighted from my wits: —O here's the watch;
Pray doe your Office, lock the doores up friends,
And patience be his Angel.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: This comes unlook'd for:

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Ile to the lodge; ſome that are kind and love me,
I know wil viſit me. Petrucho within.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.p: Doe you heare my Maſters: ho, you that locke the doores up.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Tis his voyce.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Hold, and let's heare him.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Wil ye ſtarve me here: am I a Traytor, or an Heretick.
Or am I grown infectious?

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Pray ſir, pray.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: I am as wel as you are, goodman puppy.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Pray have patience,
You ſhall want nothing ſir.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: I want a cudgell,
And thee, thou wickedneſſe.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: He ſpeakes wel enough.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Had ever a ſtrong heart ſir.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Wil ye heare me?
Firſt be pleas'd
To think I know ye all, and can diſtinguiſh
Ev'ry mans ſeverall voyce: you that ſpoke firſt,
I know my father in law; the other Tranio,
And I heard Sophocles; the laſt, pray marke me,
Is my dam;d wife Maria:
If any man miſdoubt me for infected,
There is mine arme, let any man looke on't.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: Save ye Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Petron:
sp.l: O welcome Doctor,
Ye come in happy time; pray your opinion,
What think you of his pulſe?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.l: It beats with buſieſt,
And ſhews a general inflammation,
Which is the ſymptome of a peſtilent feaver,
Take twenty ounces frow him.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Take a foole;
Take an ounce from mine arme, and Doctor Deuz-ace,
Ile make a cloſe-ſtoole of your Velvet coſtard.
—Gentlemen, doe ye make a may-game on me?
I tell ye once againe, I am as ſound,
As wel, as wholſome, and as ſenſible,
As any of ye all: Let me out quickly,
Or as I am a man, Ile beat the wals down,
And the firſt thing I light upon ſhall pay for't.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Nay we'l go with you Doctor.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Tis the ſafeſt;
I ſaw the tokens ſir.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Then there is but one way.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Wil it pleaſe you open?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: His fit grows ſtronger ſtill.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Let's ſave our ſelves ſir,
He's paſt all worldly cure.
Friends do your office.
And what he wants, if money, love, or labour,
Or any way may win it, let him have it.
Farewell, and pray my honeſt friends — Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Why Raſcals,
Friends, Gentlemen, thou beaſtly wife, Jaques;
None heare me? who at the doore there?

sp.speaker: 1 Watch.
sp.l: Thinke I pray ſir,
Whether you are going, and prepare your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: 2 Watch.
sp.l: Theſe idle thoughts diſturbe you, the good Gentlewoman
Your wife has taken care you ſhall want nothing.

sp.speaker: Petru
sp.l: Shall I come out in quiet? anſwer me,
Or ſhall I charge a fowling-piece, and make
Mine own way; two of ye I cannot miſſe,
If I miſſe three; ye come here to aſſault me.
I am as excellent wel, I thank Heav'n for't,
And have as good a ſtomacke at this inſtant—

sp.speaker: 2 Watch.
sp.l: That's an ill ſigne.

sp.speaker: 1 Watch.
sp.l: He draws on; he's a dead man,

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: And ſleep as ſoundly; wil ye looke upon me?

sp.speaker: 1 Watch.
sp.l: Do you want Pen and Inke? while you have ſence ſir,
Settle your ſtate.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Sirs, I am wel, as you are;
Or any Raſcall living.

sp.speaker: 2 Watch.
sp.l: would you were ſir.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Look to your ſelves, and if you love your lives,
Open the doore, and fly me, for I ſhoot elſe;
— Ile ſhoot, and preſently, chain-bullets;
And under foure I will not kill.

sp.speaker: 1 Watch.
sp.l: Let's quit him,
It may be it is trick: he's dangerous.

sp.speaker: 2 Watch.
sp.p: The devill take the hinmoſt, I cry. Exit watch running.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Have among ye;
The doore ſhall open too, Ile have a faire ſhoot;
Are ye all gone? tricks in my old daies, crackers
Put now upon me? and by Lady Green-ſleeves?
Am I grown ſo tame after all my triumphs?
But that I ſhould be thought mad, if I rail'd
As much as they deſerve againſt theſe women,
I would now rip up from the primitive cuckold,
All their arch-villanies, and all their dobles,
Which are more then a hunted Hare ere thought on:
When a man has the faireſt, and the ſweeteſt
Of all their ſex, and as he thinks the nobleſt,
What has he then? and Ile ſpeake modeſtly,
He has a Quartern-ague, that ſhall ſhake
All his eſtate to nothing; never cur'd,
Nor never dying; H'as a ſip to venture
His fame, and credit in, which if he man not
With more continuall labour then a Gally
To make her tith, either ſhe grows a Tumbrell
Not worth the cloth ſhe weares; or ſprings more leakes
Then all the fame of his poſterity
Can ever ſtop againe: I could raile twenty daies;
Out on 'em hedge-hogs,
He that ſhal touch 'em, has a thouſand thorns
Runs through his fingers: If I were unmarried,
I would do any thing below repentance,
Any baſe dunhill ſlavery; be a hang-man,
Ere I would be a husband: O the thouſand,
Thouſand, ten thouſand waies they have to kil us!
Some fall with too much ſtringing of the Fiddles,
And thoſe are fooles; ſome, that they are not ſuffer'd,
And thoſe are Maudlin-lovers: ſome, like Scorpions,
They poyſon with their tailes, and thoſe are Martyrs;
Some die with doing good, thoſe Benefactors,
And leave 'em land to leap away: ſome few,
For thoſe are rareſt, they are ſaid to kill
With kindneſſe, and faire uſage; but what they are
My Catologue diſcovers not: onely tis thought
They are buried in old wals with their heeles upward.
I could raile twenty daies together now.
Ile ſeek 'em out, and if I have not reaſon,
And very ſenſible, why this was done,
Ile go a birding yet, and ſome ſhall ſmart for't. Exit.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: That I do love her, is without all queſtion,
And moſt extreamly, deerly, moſt exactly;
And that I would ev'n now, this preſent Monday,
Before all others, maids, wives, women, widdows,
Of what degree or calling, marry her,
As certaine too; but to be made a whim-wham,
A Jib-crack, and a Gentleman o'th firſt houſe
For all my kindneſſe to her.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: How you take it?
Thou get a wench, thou get dozen night-caps;
Wouldſt have her come, and lick thee like a calfe,
And blow thy noſe, and buſſe thee?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Not ſo neither.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: What wouldſt thou have her do?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Do as ſhe ſhould do;
Put on a clean ſmock, and to Church, and marry,
And then to bed a Gods name, this is faire play,
And keeps the Kings peace; let her leave her bobs,
I have had too many of them, and her quillets,
She is as nimble that way as an Eele;
But in the way ſhe ought to me eſpecially,
A ſow of Lead is ſwifter.

sp.speaker: Petron
sp.l: Quoat your griefes down.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Give faire quarter, I am old and craſie,
And ſubject to much ſumbling, I confeſſe it;
Yet ſomething I would have that's warme, to hatch me:
But underſtand me I would have it ſo,
I buy not more repentance in the bargaine
Then the ware's worth I have; if you allow me
Worthy your Son-in-law, and your allowance,
Do it a way of credit; let me ſhow ſo,
And not be troubled in my viſitations,
With blows, and bitterneſſe, and down right railings,
As if we were to couple like two cats,
With clawing, add loud clamour:

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Thou fond man
Haſt thou forgot the Ballard, crabbed age,
Can May and Ianuary match together,
And nev'r a ſtorm between 'em? ſay ſhe abuſe thee,
Put caſe ſhe doe.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Wel.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Nay, believe ſhe do's.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: I doe believe ſhe do's.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: And div'liſhly:
Art thou a whit the worſe?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: That's not the matter,
I know, being old, tis fit I am abus'd;
I know tis hanſome, and I know moreover
I am to love her ſor't.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Now you come to me.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Nay more then this; I find too, and finde certain,
What Gold I have, Pearle, Bracelets, Rings, or Owches,
Or what ſhe can deſire, Gowns, Petticotes,
Waſtcotes, Enbroydered-ſtockings, Scarffs, Cals, Feathers
Hats, five pound Garters, Muffs, Masks, Ruffs, & Ribands,
I am to give her for't.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Tis right, you are ſo.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: But when I have done all this, and think it duty,
Is't requiſit an other bore my noſtrils?
Riddle me that.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Go get you gone, and dreame
She's thine within theſe two daies, for ſhe is ſo;
The boy's beſide the ſaddle: get warm broths,
And feed apace; think not of worldly buſineſſe,
It cools the blood; leave off your tricks, they are hateful,
And meere forerunners of the ancient meaſures;
Contrive your beard o'th top cut like Verdugoes;
It ſhows you would be wiſe, and burn your night-cap,
It looks like halfe a winding-ſheet, and urges
From a young wench nothing but cold repentance:
You may eate Onyons, ſo you'l not be laviſh.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: I am glad of that.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: They purge the blood, and quicken,
But after 'em, conceive me, ſweep your mouth,
And where there wants a tooth, ſtick in a clove.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Shall I hope once againe, ſay't,

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: You ſhall ſir:
And you ſhall have your hope. Enter Byancha and Tranio.

sp.speaker: Moro.
sp.l: Why there's a match then.

sp.speaker: Byan.
sp.l: You ſhall not finde me wanting, get you gon.
Here's the old man, he'l think you are plotting elſe
Something againſt his new Sonne. Exit Tranio.

sp.speaker: Moro.
sp.l: Fare ye well ſir. Exit Moroſo.

l.hi: And ev'ry Buck had his Doe,
And ev'ry Cuckold a Bell at his Toe:
Oh what ſport ſhould we have then, then Bayes then,
O what ſport ſhould we have then?

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: This is the ſpirit, that inſpires 'em all.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Give you good ev'n.

sp.speaker: Petro
sp.l: A word with you Sweet Lady.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: I am very haſty ſir.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: So your were ever.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Well what's your will?

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Was not your skilfull hand
In this laſt ſtratagem? were not your miſchiefes
Eeking the matter on?

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: In's ſhutting up?
Is that it?

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Ile tell you.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Doe,

sp.speaker: By
sp.l: And truly.
Good old man, I doe grieve exceeding much,
I feare too much.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: I am ſorry for your heavineſſe.
Belike you can repent then?

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: There you are wide too.
Not that the thing was done (conceive me rightly)
Do's any way moleſt me.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: What then Lady?

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: But that I was not in't, there's my ſorrow, there
Now you underſtand me, for Ile tell you,
It was ſo ſound a peece, and ſo well carried,
And if you marke the way, ſo hanſomely,
Of ſuch a heigth, and excellence, and art
I have not known a braver, for conceive me,
When the groſſe foole her husband would be ſick —

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Pray ſtay.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Nay, good, your patience: and no ſence for't,
Then ſtept your daughter in.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: By your appointment.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: I would it had, on that condition
I had but one halfe ſmock, I like it ſo well;
And like an excellent cunning woman, cur'd me
One madneſſe with an other, which was rare,
And to our weake beleifes, a wonder.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Hang ye,
For ſurely, if your husband looke not to ye,
I know what will.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: I humbly thank your worſhip.
And ſo I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: You have a hand I heare too.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: I have two ſir.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: In my youg daughters buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: You will finde there
A fitter hand then mine, to reach her frets,
And play down diddle to her.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: I ſhall watch ye.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Doe.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: And I ſhall have juſtice.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: That's all one;
I ſhall be with you at a turne hence forward.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Get you a poſſet too; and ſo good ev'n ſir.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: And as I told your worſhip, all the hangings,
Braſſe, Pewter, Plate, ev'n to the very looking-glaſſes.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: And that that hung for our defence, the Armor,
And the march Beere was going too: Oh Iaques
What a ſad ſight was that?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Even the two Rundlets,
The two that was our hope, of Muskadell,
(Better nev'r tongue tript over) theſe two Cannons,
To batter brawne withall at Chriſtmas, ſir
Ev'n thoſe two lovely twyns, the enemy
Had almoſt cut off cleane.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Goe trim the houſe up.
And put the things in order as they were. Exit Ped. and Iaq.
I ſhall finde time for all this: could I finde her
But conſtant any way, I had done my buſineſſe;
Were ſhe a whore directly, or a ſcold,
An unthrift, or a woman made to hate me,
I had my wiſh, and knew which way to rayne her:
But while ſhe ſhewes all theſe, and all their loſſes,
A kinde of linſey woolſey, mingled miſchiefe
Not to be gheſt at, and whether true, or borrowed,
Not certaine neither, what a hap had I, Enter Maria.
And what a tydie fortune, when my fate
Flung me upon this Beare-whelp? here ſhe comes
Now if ſhe have a colour, for the fault is
A cleanly one, upon my conſcience
I ſhall forgive her yet, and finde a ſomething
Certaine, I married for: her wit: Ile marke her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Not let his wife come neere him in his ſicknes,
Not come to comfort him? ſhe that all lawes
Of heaven, and Nations have ordain'd his ſecond,
Is ſhe refus'd? and two old Paradoxes,
Peeces of five and fifty, without faith
Clapt in upon him? h'as a little pet,
That all young wives muſt follow neceſſary
Having their Mayden-heads—

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: This is an Axiome
I never heard before.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Or ſay rebellion
If we durſt be ſo foule, which two faire words
Alas win us from, in an houre, an inſtant,
We are ſo eaſie, make him ſo forgetfull
Both of his reaſon, honeſty, and credit,
As to deny his wife a viſitation?
His wife, that (though ſhe was a little fooliſh,)
Lov'd him, Oh heaven forgive her for't! nay doted,
Nay had run mad, had ſhe not married him,

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Though I doe know this falſer then the devill,
I cannot chooſe but love it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What doe I know
But thoſe that came to keepe him, might have kill'd him,
In what a caſe had I been then? I dare not
Beleeve him ſuch a baſe, deboſh'd companion,
That one refuſall of a tender maide
Would make him faigne this ſ●ckneſſe out of need,
And take a Keeper to him of foureſcore
To play at Billiards; one that mew'd content
And all her teeth together; not come neere him?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: This woman would have made a moſt rare Jeſuite
She can prevaricate on any thing:
There was not to be thought a way to ſave her
In all imagination, beſide this.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: His unkinde dealing, which was, worſt of all,
In ſending, who knowes whether, all the plate,
And all the houſhold-ſtuffe, had I not croſt it,
By a great providence, and my friends aſſiſtance
Which he will thanke me one day for: alas,
I could have watch'd as well as they, have ſerv'd him
In any uſe, better, and willinger.
The Law commands me to doe it, love commands me.
And my own duty charges me.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Heav'n bleſſe me.
And now I have ſaid my Prayers, Ile goe to her:
Are you a wife for any man?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: For you Sir.
If I were worſe, I were better; That you are well,
At leaſt, that you appeare ſo, I thanke heaven,
Long may it hold and that you are here, I am glad too,
But that you have abus'd me wretchedly,
And ſuch a way that ſhames the name of husband,
Such a malicious mangy way, ſo mingled,
(Never looke ſtrangely on me, I dare tell you)
With breach of honeſty, care, kindneſſe, manners.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Holla, you kick too faſt.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Was I a ſtranger?
Or had I vow'd perdition to your perſon?
Am I not married to you, tell me that?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: I would I could not tell you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Is my preſence,
The ſtock I come of, which is worſhipfull,
If I ſhould ſay right worſhipfull, I ly'd not,
My Grandſire was a Knight.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: O'the Shire?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: A Souldier,
Which none of all thy Family e're heard off,
But one conductor of thy name, a Graſier
That ran away with pay: or am I grown
(Becauſe I have been a little peeviſh to you,
Onely to try your temper) ſuch a dogge-latch
I could not be admitted to your preſence?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: If I endure this, hang me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And two deaths heads,
Two Harry Groats, that had their faces worne,
Almoſt their names away too.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Now heare me.
For I will ſtay no longer.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: This you ſhall:
How ever you ſhall think to flatter me,
For this offence, which no ſubmiſſion.
Can ever mediate for, you'l finde it ſo,
What ever you ſhall doe by interceſſion,
What you can offer, what your Land can purchaſe,
What all your friends, or families can win,
Shall be but this, not to forſweare your knowledge,
But ever to forbeare it: now your will ſir.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Thou art the ſubtleſt woman I think living,
I am ſure the lewdeſt; now be ſtill, and marke me;
Were I but any way addicted to the devill,
I ſhould now think I had met a play-fellow
To profit by, and that way the moſt learned
That ever taught to murmur. Tell me thou,
Thou moſt poor, paltry ſpitefull whore: doe you cry?
Ile make you roare, before I leave.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Your pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Was it not ſinne enough, thou Fruiterer
Full of the fall thou eat'ſt: thou devils broker,
Thou Seminary of all ſedition,
Thou ſword of veng'ance, with a thred hung o're us,
Was it not ſinne enough, and wickednes
In full abundance? was it not vexation
At all points, cap a pe? nay, I ſhall pinch you,
Thus like a rotten raſcall to abuſe.
The name of heaven, the tye of marriage,
The honour of thy friends; the expectation
Of all that thought thee vertuous, with rebellion,
Childiſh and baſe rebellion, but continuing.
After forgiveneſſe too, and worſe, your miſchiefe,
And againſt him ſetting the hope of heaven by,
And the deere reſervation of his honour
Nothing above ground could have won to hate thee:
Well goe thy wayes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: You ſhall heare me out firſt:
What puniſhment mai'ſt thou deſerve, thou thing,
Thou Idle thing of nothing, thou pull'd Primroſe,
That two houres after, art a weed, and wither'd,
For this laſt flouriſh on me? am I one
Selected out of all the husbands living,
To be ſo ridden by a Tit of ten pence,
Am I ſo blind and Bed-rid? I was mad,
And had the Plague, and no man muſt come neere me,
I muſt be ſhut up, and my ſubſtance bezel'd,
And an old woman watch me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Well ſir, well,
You may well glory in't.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: And when it comes to opening, 'tis my plot,
I muſt undoe my ſelfe forſooth: do'ſt heare me?
If I ſhould beat thee now, as much may be,
Do'ſt thou not well deſerve it, o' thy conſcience,
Do'ſt thou not cry, come beat me?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I defie you.
And my laſt loving teares farwell: the firſt ſtroke,
The very firſt you give me if you dare ſtrike,
Try me, and you ſhall finde it ſo, for ever
Never to be recall'd: I know you love me,
Mad till you have enjoy'd me; I doe turne
Utterly from you, and what man I meet firſt,
That has but ſpirit to deſerve a favour,
Let him beare any ſhape, the worſe the better,
Shall kill you, and enjoy me; what I have ſaid
About your fooliſh ſickneſſe, e're you have me
As you would have me, you ſhall ſweare, is certaine,
And challenge any man, that dares deny it;
And in all companies approve my actions,
And ſo farwell for this time. Exit Mar.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Grief goe with thee,
If there be any witchcrafts, herbes, or potions,
Saying my Prayers back-ward, Fiends, or Fayries
That can againe unlove me, I am made. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Miſtreſſe, you muſt doe it.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Are the writings ready I told you of?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Yes they are ready, but to what uſe I know not.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Y'are an Aſſe, you muſt have all things conſtru'd,

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Yes, and peirc'd too,
Or I finde little pleaſure.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Now you are knaviſh,
Goe too, fetch Rowland hither preſently,
Your twenty pound lies bleeding elſe: ſhe is married
Within theſe twelve houres, if we croſſe it not,
And ſee the Papers of one ſize.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I have ye.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: And for diſpoſing of 'em.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: If I faile you
Now I have found the way, uſe Marſhall Law
And cut my head off with a hand Saw:

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Wel ſir.
Petronius and Moroſo I'le ſee ſent for
About your buſineſſe; goe.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I am gone. Exit Tra.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Ho Livia. Enter Livia.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: A friend of yours, Lord how you looke now,
As if you had loſt a Carrick.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: O Byancha.
I am the moſt undone, unhappy woman.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Be quiet wench, thou ſhalt be done, and done,
And done, and double done, or all ſhall ſplit for't,
No more of theſe minc'd paſſions, they are mangy,
And eaſe thee of nothing, but a little wind,
An apple will doe more: thou fear'ſt Moroſo.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Even as I feare the Gallowes.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Keepe thee there ſtill.
And you love Rowland? ſay.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: If I ſay not
I am ſure I lye.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: What would'ſt thou give that woman,
In ſpight of all his anger, and thy feare,
And all thy Fathers policy, that could
Clap ye within theſe two nights quietly
Into a Bed together?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Why fairely,
At half ſword man and wife: now the red blood comes,
I marry now the matters chang'd.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Me thinks you ſhould not mock me.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Mock a pudding.
I ſpeake good honeſt Engliſh, and good meaning.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: I ſhould not be ungratefull to that woman.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: I know thou would'ſt not, follow but my Counpell
And if thou haſt him not, deſpight of fortune
Let me nev'r know a good night more; you muſt
Be very ſick o'th inſtant.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Well, what follows?

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: And in that ſickneſſe ſend for all your friends,
Your Father, and your feavor old Moroſo,
And Rowland ſhall be there too.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: What of theſe?

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Doe you not twitter yet? of this ſhall follow
That which ſhall make thy heart leape, and thy lips
Venture as many kiſſes, as the Merchants
Doe dollars to the East-Indies: you ſhall know all,
But firſt walke in, and practiſe, pray be ſick.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: I doe beleeve you: and I am ſick.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Doe
To bed then, come, Ile ſend away your Servants
Poſt for your Foole, and Father; and good fortune,
As we meane honeſty, now ſtrike an up-ſhot. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Nay, on my conſcience, I have loſt my money,
But that's all one: Ile never more perſwade you,
I ſee you are reſolute, and I commend you.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: But did ſhe ſend for me?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: You dare beleeve me.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: I cannot tell, you have your waies for profit
Allow'd you Tranio, as well as I
Have to avoid 'em feare:

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: No, on my word ſir
l deale directly with you. Enter Servant.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: How now fellow,
Whither Poſt you ſo faſt?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: O ſir my Maſter
Pray did you ſee my Maſter?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Why your Maſter?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Sir his Jewell.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: With the gilded Button?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: My pretty Miſtreſſe Livia.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: What of her?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Is falne ſick o'th ſuddaine.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: How o'th ſullens?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: O'th ſuddaine ſir, I ſay, very ſick:

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: It ſeemes ſhe hath got the toothach with raw apples.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: It ſeemes you have got the headach, fare you well ſir.
You did not ſee my Maſter?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Who told you ſo?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: No, no, he did not ſee him.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Farewell blew bottle. Exit Servant.
What ſhould her ſickneſſe be?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: For you it may be.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Yes when my braines are out, I may beleeve it,
Never before I am ſure: yet I may ſee her
'Twill be a point of honeſty:

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: It will ſo.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: It may be not too: you would faine be fingring
This old ſinne-offring of two hundred, Tranio,
How daintily, and cunningly you drive me
Up like a Deere to'th toyle, yet I may leape it,
And what's the woodman then?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: A looſer by you.
Speake will you go or not? to me 'tis equall.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Come what goes leſſe?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Nay not a penny Rowland.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Shall I have liberty of conſcience
Which by interpretation, is ten kiſſes?
Hang me if I affect her: yet it may be,
This whorſon manners will require a ſtrugling,
Of two and twenty, or by'r-Lady thirty.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: By'r-lady Ile require my wager then,
For if you kiſſe ſo often, and no kindneſſe,
I have loſt my ſpeculation, i'le allow you —

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Speake like a Gamſter now.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: It may be two.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Under a dozen Tranio 'ther's no ſettings,
You ſhall have forty ſhillings, winck at ſmall faults.
Say I take twenty, come, by all that's honeſt
I doe it but to vex her.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Ile no by-lowes.
If you can love her doe, if you can hate her,
Or any elſe that loves you.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Prethee Tranio.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Why farewell twenty pound, twill not undoe me;
You have my reſolution.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: And your money,
Which ſince you are ſo ſtubborne, if I forfeit,
Make me a Jack o' Lent, and breake ſhins
For untag'd points and Compters: Ile goe with you,
But if thou gett'ſt a penny by the bargaine;
A parting kiſſe is lawfull?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I allow it.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Knock out my braines with Apples; yet a bargaine:

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I tell you, i'le no bargaines; win, and weare it.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Thou art the ſtrangeſt fellow.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: That's all one.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Along then, twenty pound more if thou dar'ſt,
I give her not a good word.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Not a Penny. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Prethee, entreat her come, I will not trouble her Exit Pedro.
Above a word or two; ere I endure
This life, and with a woman, and a vow'd one
To all the miſchiefes ſhe can lay upon me,
Ile goe to Plough again, and eat leeke Porridge;
Begging's a pleaſure to 't not to be numberd:
No there be other Countries Iaques for me, and other people, yea, and other women.
If I have need, here's money, there's your ware,
Which is faire dealing, and the Sunne, they ſay
Shines as warme there, as here, and till I have loſt
Either my ſelfe, or her, I care not whether
Nor which firſt.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Will your worſhip heare me?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: And utterly outworne the memory
Of ſuch a curſe as this, none of my Nation
Shall ever know me more.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Out alas ſir
What a ſtrange way doe you runne?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Any way,
So I out-runne this raſcall.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Me thinkes now,
If your good worſhip could but have the patience.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: The patience, why the patience?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Why i'le tell you,
Could you but have the patience.

sp.speaker: Peru.
sp.l: Well the patience.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: To laugh at all ſhe do's, or when ſhe railes,
To have a drum beaten o'th top o'th houſe,
To give the neighbours warning of her Larme,
As I doe when my wife rebels.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Thy wife?
Thy wife's a Pigeon to her a meere ſlumber,
The dead of night's not ſtiller.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Nor an Iron Mill.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: But thy wife is certaine.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: That's falſe Doctrine,
You never read of a certaine woman.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Thou know'st her way.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.l: I ſhould doe, I am ſure.
I have ridden it night, and day, this twenty yeare.

sp.speaker: Petri.
sp.l: But mine is ſuch a drench of Balderdaſh,
Such a ſtrange carded cunningneſſe, the Rayne-bow
When ſhe hangs bent in heaven, ſheds not her colours
Quicker and more then this deceitfull woman Enter Ped.
Weaves in her dyes of wickedneſſe: what ſayes ſhe?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Nay not a word ſir, but ſhe pointed to me,
As though ſhe meant to follow; pray ſir bear it
Ev'n as you may, I need not teach your worſhip,
The beſt men have their croſſes, we are all mortall.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: What ailes the fellow?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: And no doubt ſhe may ſir

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: What may ſhe, or what do's ſhe, or what is ſhe?
Speake and be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: She's mad Sir.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Heaven continue it.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Amen if't be his pleaſure

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: How mad is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: As mad as heart can wiſh ſir: ſhe has dreſt her ſelf
(Saving your worſhips reverence) iuſt i'th cut
Of one of thoſe that multiply i'th Suburbs
For ſingle money, and as durtily:
If any ſpeake to her, firſt ſhe whiſtles,
And then begins her compaſſe with her fingers,
And points to what ſhe would have.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: What new waye's this?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: There came in Maſter Sophocles,

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: And what
Did Maſter Sophocles when he came in?
Get my Truncks ready ſirha, i'le be gone straight.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: He's here to tell you Enter Sophocles.
She's horne mad Iaques.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Call ye this a woman?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Yes ſir, ſhe is a woman,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Sir, I doubt it.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: I had thought you had make experience,

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Yes I did ſo.
And almoſt with my life.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: You rid too faſt ſir.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Pray be not miſtaken: by this hand
Your wife's as chaſte, and honeſt as a virgin,
For any thing I know: 'tis true ſhe gave me
A Ring.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: For rutting.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: You are much deceiv'd ſtill,
Beleeve me, I never kiſt her ſince, and now
Coming in viſitation, like a friend,
I thinke ſhe is mad ſir, ſuddainly ſhe ſtarted,
And ſnatch'd the Ring away, and drew her knife out,
To what intent I know not.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Is this certaine?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: As I am here ſir.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: I beleeve ypvi honeſt. Enter Maria.
And pray continue ſo.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: She comes.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Now Damſell,
What will your beauty doe, if I forſake you?
Doe you deale by ſignes, and tokens? as I gheſſe then,
You'l walke abroad, this Sommer, and catch Captaines,
Or hire a peece of holy ground i'th Suburbs,
And keepe a neaſt of Nuns?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: O doe not ſtir her!
You ſee in what a caſe ſhe is?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: She is dogged,
And in a beaſtly caſe I am ſure: Ile make her
If ſhe have any tongue, yet tatle Sophocles
Prethee obſerve this woman ſeriouſly,
And eye her well, and when thou haſt done, but tell me
(For thou haſt underſtanding) in what caſe
My ſence was, when I choſe this thing.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Ile tell you
I have ſeene a ſweeter—

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: An hundred times cry oyſters.
Ther's a poore Begger wench about Black-Fryers
Runs on her breech may be an Empreſſe to her.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Nay, now you are too bitter.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Nev'r a whit ſir:
Ile tell thee woman; for now I have day to ſee thee,
And all my wits about me, and I ſpeake
Not out of paſſion neither (leave your mumping)
I know you're well enough: Now would I give
A million but to vex her: when I choſe thee
To make a Bedfellow, I tooke more trouble,
Then twenty Termes can come too, ſuch a cauſe
Of ſuch a title, and ſo everlaſting
That Adams Genealogie may be ended
Ere any law find thee: I tooke a Leproſie,
Nay worſe, the plague, nay worſe yet, a poſſeſſion
And had the devill with thee, if not more:
And yet worſe, was a beaſt, and like a beaſt
Had my reward, a Jade to fiing my fortunes;
For who that had but reaſon to diſtinguiſh
The light from darkneſſe, wine from water, hunger
from full ſaciety, and Fox from ferne buſh
That would have married thee?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: She is not ſo ill.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: She's worſe then I dare think of: ſhe's ſo lewd,
No Court is ſtrong enough to bear her cauſe.
She hath neither manners, honeſty, behavour,
Wiſe-hood, nor woman-hood, nor any morall
Can force me think ſhe had a mother, no
I do believe her ſtedfaſtly, and know her
To be a woman-Woolfe by tranſmigration,
Her firſt forme was a Ferrets undergrounde,
She kils the memories of men: not yet?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Do you think ſhe's ſenſible of this?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: I care not,
Be what ſhe will the pleaſure I take in her,
Thus I blow off, the care I took to love her,
Like this point I unty, and thus I looſe it,
The husband I am to her, thus I ſever:
My vanity farwell: yet, for you have bin
So neer me as to bear the name of wife,
My unquench'd charity ſhall tell you thus much
(Though you deſerve it well) you ſhall not beg,
What I ordan'd your Jointure, honeſtly
You ſhall have ſetled on you: and half my houſe,
The other half ſhall be imploy'd in prayers,
(That meritorious charge Ile beat alſo
Yet to confirm you chriſtian) your apparrell,
And what belongs to build up ſuch a folly,
Keep I beſeech you, it infects our uſes,
And now I am for travell.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Now I love you,
And now I ſee you are a man ile talk to you,
And I forget your bitterneſſe.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: How now man?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: O Pliny, if thou wilt be ever famous
Make but this woman all thy wonders.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sure ſir
You have hit upon a happy courſe, a bleſſed,
And what will make you vertuous?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: She'l ſhip me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: A way of underſtanding I long wiſhd for,
And now tis come, take heed you fly not back ſir,
Me thinks you look a new man to me now,
A man of excellence, and now I ſee
Some great deſign ſet in you: you may think now
(And ſo may moſt that know me) 'twere my part
Weakly to weep your loſſe, and to reſiſt you,
Nay hang about your neck and like a dotard
Urge my ſtrong tie upon you: but I love you,
And all the world ſhall know it, beyond woman,
And more prefer the honour of your Country,
Which chiefly you are born for, and may perfect,
The uſes you may make of other Nations,
The ripening of your knowledge, converſation,
The full ability, and ſtrength of judgement,
Then any private love, or wanton kiſſes.
Go worthy man, bring home underſtanding.

sp.speaker: So●h.
sp.l: This were an excellent woman to breed School|men.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: For if the Merchant through unknown Seas plough
To get his wealth, then deer ſir, what muſt you
To gather wiſdome? go, and go alone,
Only your noble mind for your companion,
And if a woman may win credit with you,
Go far: too far you cannot: ſtill the farther
The more experience finds you: and go ſparing,
One meale a week will ſerve you, and one ſute,
Through all your travels: for you'l find it certaine,
The poorer and the baſer you appear,
The more you look through ſtill.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Do'ſt hear her?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: What would this woman do if ſhe were ſuffer'd,
Upon a new adventure?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Make us nothing,
I wonder that ſhe writes not.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Then when time,
And fulneſſe of occaſion have new made you,
And ſquard you from a ſot into a Signour,
Or neerer from a lade into a courſer;
Come home an aged man, as did Ʋlyſses,
And I your glad Penelope.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: That muſt have
As many lovers as I languages,
And what ſhe do's with one i'th day, i'th night
Undoe it with an other.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Much that way ſir;
For in your abſence, it muſt be my honour,
That, that muſt make me ſpoken of hereafter,
To have temptations, and not little ones
Daily and hourely offerd me, and ſtrongly,
Almoſt believed againſt me, to ſet off
The faith, and loyalty of her that loves you

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: What ſhould I do?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Why by my—I would travell,
Did not you mean ſo?

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Alas no, nothing leſſe man:
I did it but to try ſir, ſhee's the devill,
And now I find it, for ſhe drives me, I muſt go:
Are my trunks down there, and my horſes ready?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Sir, for your houſe, and if you pleaſe to truſt me
With that you leave behinde.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Bring down the money.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: As I am able, and to my poor fortunes,
I'le govern as a widow: I ſhall long
To hear of your wel-doing, and your profit:
And when I hear not from you once a quarter,
I'le wiſh you in the Indies, or Cataya,
Thoſe are the climes muſt make you.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: How's the wind?
She'l wiſh me out o'th world anon.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: For France.
Tis very faire; get you aboard to night ſir,
And looſe no time, you know the tide ſtaies no man,
I have cold meats ready for you.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Far thee well.
Thou ha'ſt foold me o'th Kingdom with a vengeance,
And thoue canſt foole me in againe.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Not I ſir,
I love you better, take your time, and pleaſure.
Ile ſee you horſd.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: I think thou wouldſt ſee me hangd too,
Were I but halfe as willing.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Any thing
That you think well of, I dare look upon.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: You'l bear me to the lands end Sophocles,
And other of my friends I hope.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Nev'r doubt ſir,
You cannot want companions for your good:
I am ſure you'l kiſſe me ere I go; I have buſineſſe,
And ſtay long here I muſt not.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Get thee going.
For if thou tarrieſt but an other Dialogue
Ile kick thee to thy Chamber.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Far you well Sir,
And bear your ſelfe, I do beſeech you once more,
Since you have undertaken doing wiſely,
Manly, and worthily, tis tor my credit,
And for thoſe flying fames here of your follies,
Your gambols, and ill breeding of your youth,
For which I underſtand you take this travell,
Nothing ſhould make me leave you els, ile deale
So like a wife, that loves your reputation,
And the moſt large addition of your credit,
That thoſe ſhall die: if you want Limon-waters,
Or any thing to take the edge o'th Sea off,
Pray ſpeak, and be provided.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Now the Devill,
That was your firſt good maſter, ſhoure his bleſſing
Upon ye all: into whoſe cuſtody—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I do commit your Reformation,
And ſo I leave you to your Stilo novo. Exit Maria

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: I will go: yet I will not: once more Sophocles
Ile put her to the teſt.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: You had better go.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: I will go then: let's ſeek my father out,
And all my friends to ſee me faire aboard:
Then women, if there be a ſtorme at Sea,
Worſe then your tongues can make, and waves more broken
Then your diſſembling fayths are, let me feele
Nothing but tempeſts, till they cracke my Keele.

div.head: Scaena Prima.
div.stage: Enter Petronius, and Byancha with foure papers.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Now whether I deſerve that blame you gave me,
Let all the world diſcern ſir.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: If this motion,
(I mean this fair repentance of my Daughter)
Spring from your good perſwaſion, as it ſems ſo,
I muſt confeſſe I have ſpoke too boldly of you,
And I repent.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: The firſt touch was her own,
Taken no doubt from diſobeying you,
The ſecond I put to her, when I told her
How good, and gentle yet, with free contrition
Again you might be purchas'd: loving woman,
She heard me, and I thank her, thought me worthy
Obſerving in this point: yet all my councell,
And comfort in this caſe, could not ſo heal her
But that grief got his ſhare too, and ſhe ſickend.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: I am ſorry ſhe's ſo ill, yet glad her ſickneſſe
Ha's got ſo good a ground. Enter Moroſo.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Here comes Moroſo.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: O you are very welcome,
Now you ſhall know your happineſſe.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: I am glad on't.
What makes this Lady here?

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: A diſh for you ſir
You'l thank me for hereafter.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: True Moroſo,
Go get you in, and ſee your Miſtris.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: She is ſick ſir,
But you may kiſſe her whole.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: How.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: Comfort her.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: VVhy am I ſent for ſir?

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Will you in, and ſee?

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: May be ſhe needs confeſſion.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: By St. Mary,
She ſhall have abſolution then and pennance,
But not above her carriage.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Get you in foole. Exit. Mor.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.p: Here comes the other too. En. Rowland and Tranio.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Now Tranio.
Good ev'n to you too, and you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Thank you.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: I have a certaine Daughter.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Would you had ſir.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: No doubt you know her well.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Nor never ſhall ſir.
She is a woman, and the waies unto her
Are like the finding of a certaine path
After a deep falne Snow.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Well thats by'th by ſtill.
This Daughter that I tell you of is falne
A little crop ſick, with the dangerous ſurfeit
She took of your affection.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Mine ſir?

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Yes ſir.
Or rather, as it ſeemes, repenting.
And there ſhe lies within, debating on't,

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Well ſir.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: I think 'twere well you would ſee her.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: If you pleaſe ſir;
I am not ſqueamiſh of my viſitation.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: But, this ile tell you, ſhe is alter'd much,
You'l finde her now an other Livia.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: I have enough o'th old ſir.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: No more foole,
To look gay babies in your eyes yong Rowland,
And hang about your prety neck.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: I am glad on't,
And thank my Fates I have ſcapd ſuch execution,

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: And buſſe you till you bluſh againe.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Thats hard ſir,
She muſt kiſſe ſhamefully ere I bluſh at it,
I never was ſo boyiſh; well, what followes?

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: She's mine now, as I pleaſe to ſettle her,
At my command, and where I pleaſe to plant her:
Only ſhe would take a kind of farwell of you,
And give you back a wandring vow or two,
You left in pawn; and two or three ſlight oaths
She lent you too, ſhe looks for.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: She ſhall have 'em
With all my heart ſir, and if you like it better,
A free releaſe in writing.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Thats the matter,
And you from her, you ſhall have an other Rowland,
And then turne taile to taile, and peace by with you.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: So be it: your twenty pound ſweats Tranio.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: 'Twill not undoe me Rowland, do your worſt.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Come, ſhall we ſee her Sir?

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: What ere ſhe ſaies
You muſt beare manly Rowland, for her ſickneſſe
Has made he rſomewhat teatiſh.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Let her talke
Till her tongue ake I care not: by this hand
Thou haſt a handſome face wench, and a body
Daintely mounted; now do I feele an hundred
Runing directly from me, as I piſt it.
sp.stage: Enter Livia diſcovered abed, and Moroſo by her.

sp.speaker: By.
sp.l: pray draw 'em ſoftly, the leaſt hurry ſir
Puts her to much impatience.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: How is't daughter?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: O very ſick, very ſick, yet ſomewhat
Better I hope; a little lightſommer,
Becauſe this goodman has forgiven me;
Pray ſet me higher; Oh my head:

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Wel done wench.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Father, and all good people that ſhal heare me,
I have abus'd this man perniciouſly; was never old man humbled ſo;
I have ſcornd him, and cal'd him naſty names,
I have ſpit at him,
Flung Candles ends in's beard, and cald him harrow,
That muſt be drawn to all he dos: contemn'd him,
For me thought then he was a beaſtly fellow.
(Oh God my ſide) a very beaſtly fellow.
And gave it out, his caſſock was a Barge-cloth,
Pawnd to his predeceffor by a Sculler,
The man yet living: I gave him purging-comfits
At a great chriſtning once,
That ſpoyl'd his Chamblet breeches; and one night
I ſtrewd the ſtaires with peaſe, as he paſt down;
And the good Gentleman (woe worth me for't)
Ev'n with his reverent head, this head of wiſdome,
Told two and twenty ſtaires, good and true;
Miſt not a ſtep, and as we ſay verbatim
Fell to the bottome, broke his caſting Bottle,
Loſt a fair toad-ſtone of ſome eighteen ſhillings,
Jumbled his joynts together, had two ſtooles,
And was tranſlated. All this villany
Did I: I Livia, I alone, untaught.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: And I unask'd, forgive it.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Where's Byancha?

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Here Cozen.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Give me drinke,

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: There.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: O'my diſſembler, you and I muſt part.
Come neerer ſir.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: I am ſorry for your ſickneſſe.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Be ſorry for your ſelfe ſir, you have wrong'd me,
But I forgive you; are the papers ready?

sp.speaker: Bya
sp.l: I have'em here: wilt pleaſe you view 'em?

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Shew 'em the young man too, I know he's willing
To ſhift his ſailes too: tis for his more advancement;
Alas, we might have beggerd one another;
We are young both, and a world of children
Might have been left behind to curſe our follies:
We had been undone Byancha, had we married,
Undone for ever: I confeſſe I lov'd him,
I care not who ſhall know it, moſt intirely;
And once, upon my conſcience, he lov'd me;
But farewell that, we muſt be wiſer coſen.
Love muſt not leave us to the world: have you done?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Yes, and am ready to ſubſcribe.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Pray ſtay then:
Give me the papers, and let me paruſe 'em,
And ſo much time, as may afford a teare
At our laſt parting.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Pray retire, and leave her,
Ile call ye preſently.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Come Gentlemen, the ſhowre muſt fall.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Would I had never ſeen her.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Thou haſt done bravely wench.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Pray Heaven it prove ſo.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: There are the other papers: when they come
Begin you firſt, and let the reſt ſubſcribe
Hard by your ſide; give 'em as little light
As Drapers doe their wares.

sp.speaker: Liv
sp.l: Didſt mark Moroſo,
In what an agony he was, and how he cry'd moſt
When I abus'd him moſt?

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: That was but reaſon.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Oh what a ſtinking thief is this?
Though I was but to counterfeit, he made me
Directly ſick indeed. Tames-ſtreet to him
Is a meere Pomander.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Let him be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Amen.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: And lie you ſtill.
And once more to your buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Call 'em in.
Now if there be a power that pities lovers,
Helpe now, and heare my prayers.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Is ſhe ready?

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: She has done her lamentations: pray go to her.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Rowland, come neer me, and before you ſeale,
Give me your hand: take it again; now kiſſe me,
This is the laſt acquaintance we muſt have;
I wiſh you ever happy: there's the paper.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Pray ſtay a little.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Let me never live more
But I do begin to pity this young fellow;
How heartily he weeps!

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: There's Pen and Inke ſir.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Ev'n here I pray you. Tis a little Emblem
How neere you have been to me.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: There..

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Your hands too,
As witneſſes.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: By any means
To th' booke ſonne.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: You muſt deliver it.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: There Livia, and a better love light on thee,
I can no more.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: To this you muſt be witneſſe too.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: We wil.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Doe you deliver it now.

sp.speaker: Lyv.
sp.l: Pray ſet me up;
There Rowland, all thy old love back: and may
A new to come exceed mine, and be happy.
I muſt no more.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Farewell:

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: A long farewell. Exit Rowl.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Leave herby any means, till this wild paſſion
Be off her head; draw all the Curtaines cloſe,
A day hence you may ſee her, twil be better,
She is now for little company.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Pray tend her.
I muſt to horſe ſtraight: you muſt needs along too,
To ſee my ſonne aboard; were but his wife
As ſit for pity, as this wench, I were happy.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Time muſt do that too: fare ye wel; to morrow
You ſhall receive a wife to quit your ſorrow. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena ſecunda.
div.stage: Enter Jaques, Pedro, and Porters, with Cheſt and Hampers.

sp.speaker: Jag.
sp.l: Bring 'em away ſirs.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Muſt the great Trunks go too

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Yes, and the Hampers; nay be ſpeedy Maſters;
He'l be at Sea before, us elſe.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: O Jaques,
What a moſt bleſſed turn haſt thou?

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: I hope ſo.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: To have the Sea between thee and this woman,
Nothing can drown her tongue, but a ſtorm.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: By your leave,
We'l get us up to Paris with all ſpeed;
For on my ſoule, as far as Amyens
She'l carry blanke; away to Lyon key
And ſhip 'em preſently, we'l follow ye.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Now could I wiſh her in that Trunk:

sp.speaker: Jaq
sp.l: God ſhield man,
I had rather have a Beare in't.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Yes, Ile tell ye:
For in the paſſage if a Tempeſt take ye,
As many doe, and you lie beating for it,
Then, if it pleaſ'd the fates, I would have the Maſter
Out of a powerfull providence, to cry,
Lighten the ſhip of all hands, or we periſh;
Then this for one, as beſt ſpar'd, ſhould by all means
Over-board preſently.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: O' that condition,
So we were certaine to be rid of her,
I would wiſh her with us: But believe me Pedro,
She would ſpoyle the fiſhing on this coaſt for ever,
For none would keepe her company, but Dog-fiſh,
As curriſh as her ſelfe; or Porpiſces,
Made to all fatall uſes: The two Fiſh-ſtreets
Were ſhe but once ariv'd amongſt the Whitings,
Would ſing a wofull miſereri Pedro,
And mourn in poor John, till her memory
Were caſt o' ſhore agen, with a ſtrong Sea-breach:
She would make god Neptune, and his fire-forke,
And all his demi-gods, and goddeſſes,
As weary of the Flemmiſh channell Pedro,
As ever boy was of the ſchoole: tis certain,
If ſhe but meet him faire, and were wel angred,
She would break his god-head.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Oh her tongue, her tongue.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Rather her many tongues.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Or rather ſtrange tongues.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Her lying tongue.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Her liſping tongue.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Her long tongue.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Her lawleſſe tongue.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Her loud tongue.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: And her lickriſh —

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Many other tongues, and many ſtranger tongues
Then ever Babel had to tell his ruines,
Were women rais'd withall; but never a true one.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Home with your ſtuffe agen; the journeys ended.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: What do's your worſhip meane?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Your Maſter, O Petruobio, O poore fellows.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: O Jaques, Jaques.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: O your, Maſter's dead,
His body comming back; his wife, his devil;
The grieſe of— her

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Has kild him?

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Kild him, kild him.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Is there no law to hang her.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Get ye in,
And let her know her miſery, I dare not
For feare impatience ſeize me, ſee her more,
I muſt away agen: Bid her for wife-hood,
For honeſty, if ſhe have any in her,
Even to avoyd the ſhame that follows her.
Cry if ſhe can: your weeping cannot mend it.
The body wil be here within this houre, ſo tell her;
And all his friends to curſe her. Farewell fellowes.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: O Jaques, Jaques.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: O my worthy Maiſter.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: O my moſt beaſtly Miſtris, hang her.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Split her.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Drown her directly.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Starve her.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: Stinke upon her.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Stone her to death: may all ſhe eate be Eggs,
Till ſhe run kicking mad for men.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.l: And he,
That man, that gives her remedy, pray Heav'n
He may ev'n ipſo facto, loſe his longings.

sp.speaker: Jaq.
sp.l: Let's goe diſcharge our ſelves, and he that ſerves her,
Or ſpeaks a good word of her from this houre,
A ſeagly curſe light on him, which is, Pedro;
The feind ride through him booted, and ſpurd, with a Sythe at's back. Exeunt.

div.head: Scena tertia.
div.stage: Enter Rowland, and Tranio ſtealing behind him.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: What a dull aſſe was I to let her go thus?
Upon my life ſhe loves me ſtill: wel Paper,
Thou onely monument of what I have had,
Thou all the love now left me, and now loſt,
Let me yet kiſſe her hand, yet take my leave
Of what I muſt leave evere Farewell Livia.
Oh bitter words, Ile read ye once again,
And then for ever ſtudy to forget ye.
How's this? let me look better on 't: A Contract?
— a Contract, ſeal'd, and ratified,
Her fathers hand ſet to it, and Maroſo'st
I do not dream ſure, let me read again,
The ſame ſtill: tis a contract.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Tis ſo Rowlands;
And by the vertue of the ſame, you pay me
An hundred pound to morrow.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Art ſure Tranio,
We are both alive now?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Wonder not, ye have loſt.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: If this be true, I grant it.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Tis moſt certaine,
There's a Ring for you to, you know it.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: When ſhall I have my money?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Stay ye, ſtay ye,
When ſhall I marry her?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: To night.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Take heed now
You do not trifle me; if you doe,
You'l finde more payment, then your money comes to:
Come ſweare; I know I am a man, and finde
I may deceive my ſelfe: Sweare faithfully,
Sweare me directly, am I Rowland?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Am I awake?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Ye are.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Am I in health?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: As far as I conceive.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Was I with Livia?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: You were, and had his contract.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: And ſhall I enjoy her?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Yes, if ye dare.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Sweare to all theſe.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: As thou art honeſt, as thou haſt a conſcience,
As that may wring thee if thou lyeſt; all theſe
To be no viſion, but a truth, and ſerious.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Then by my honeſty, and faith, and conſcience;
All this is certaine.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Let's remove our places.
Sweare it again.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: By—tis true.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: I have loſt then, and Heaven knows I am glad out.
Let's goe, and tell me all, and tell me how,
For yet I am a Pagan in it.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: I have a Prieſt too,
And all ſhall come as even as two Teſters. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Quarta.
div.stage: Enter Petronius, Sophocles, Moroſo, and Petruchio born in a Coffin.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Set down the body, and one call her out.
sp.stage: Enter Maria in blacke, and Jaques.
sp.l: You are welcome to the laſt caſt of your fortunes;
There lies your husband, there your loving husband,
There he that was Petruchio, too good for ye;
Your ſtubborn, and unworthy way has kild him
Ere he could reach the Sea; if ye can weep,
Now ye have cauſe begin, and after death
Do ſomething yet to th'world, to thinke ye honeſt.
So many teares had ſav'd him, ſhed in time;
And as they are (ſo a good mind goe with 'em)
Yet they may move compaſſion.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Pray ye all heare me,
And judge me as I am, not as you covet,
For that would make me ye more miſerable:
Tis true, I have cauſe to grieve, and mighty cauſe;
And truely and unfainedly I weep it.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: I ſee there's ſome good nature yet left in her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: But what's the cauſe? miſtake me not, not this man,
As he is dead, I weep for; Heaven defend it,
I never was ſo childiſh: but his life,
His poore unmanly wretched fooliſh life,
Is that my full eyes pity, there's my mourning.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Doſt thou not ſhame?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I do, and even to water,
To think what this man was, to think how ſimple,
How far below a man, how far from reaſon,
From common underſtanding, and all Gentry,
While he was living here he walkt amongſt us.
He had a happy turn he dyed; ile tell ye,
Theſe are the wants I weep for, not his perſon:
The memory of this man, had he liv'd
But two yeers longer, had begot more follies,
Then wealthy Autumne flyes: But let him reſt,
He was a foole, and farewell he; not pitied,
I meane in way of life, or action
By any underſtanding man that's honeſt;
But onely in's poſterity, which I
Out of the feare his ruines might out live him
In ſome bad iſſue, like a carefull woman,
Like one indeed born onely to preſerve him,
Denyd him meanes to raiſe.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Unbutton me,
—I die indeed elſe? O Maria,
Oh my unhappineſſe, my miſery.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: Go to him whore;—if he periſh,
Ile ſee thee hang'd my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Why, why Maria.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I have done my worſt, and have my end, forgive me;
From this houre make me what you pleaſe: I have tam'd ye,
And now am vowd your ſervant: Look not ſtrangly,
Nor feare what I ſay to you. Dare you kiſſe me?
Thus I begin my new love.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Once againe?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Once again Miria!
O Gentlemen, I Know not where I am.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: Get ye to bed then: there you'l quickly know ſir.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Never no more your old tricks?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Never ſir.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: You ſhall not need, for as I have a faith
No cauſe ſhall give occaſion.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: As I am honeſt,
And as I am a maid yet, all my life
From this houre ſince, ſince ye make ſo free profeſſion,
I dedicate in ſervice to your pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Soph.
sp.l: I marry, this goes roundly off.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Go Jaques,
Get all the beſt meat may be bought for money,
And let the hogſheds blood, I am born again:
Well little England, when I ſee a husband
Of any other Nation ſtern or jealous,
Ile wiſh him but a woman of thy breeding,
And if he have not butter to thy bread,
Till thy teeth bleed, ile never truſt my travell.

div.stage: Enter Rowland, Livia, Byancha, and Tranio.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: What have we here?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Another morris, ſir.
That you muſt pipe too.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: A poore married couple
Deſire an offering ſir.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Never frown at it,
You cannot mend it now: there's your own hand;
And yours Moroſo, to confirme the bargaine.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: My hand?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Or mine?

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: You'l finde it ſo.

sp.speaker: Petron.
sp.l: A trick.
By — a trick.

sp.speaker: Bya.
sp.l: Yes ſir, we trickt ye.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Father.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Haſt thou lyen with him? ſpeake?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Yes truly ſir.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: And haſt thou done the deed boy?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: I have done ſir,
That, that will ſerve the turne, I think.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: A match then,
Ile be the maker up of this: Moroſo,
There's now no remedy you ſee, be willing;
For be, or be not, he muſt have the wench.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Since I am over-reach'd, let's in to dinner,
And if I can Ile drink't away.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: That's wel ſaid.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.l: Well ſirha, you have playd a tricke, look to't,
And let me be a grandſire within's twelvemoneth,
Or by this hand, Ile curtaile halfe your fortunes.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: There ſhall not want my labour ſir: your money;
Here's one has undertaken.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Well, Ile truſt her,
And glad I have ſo good a pawn.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Ile watch ye.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.l: Lets in, and drink of all hands, and be joviall:
I have my colt again, and now ſhe carries;
And Gentlemen, whoever marries next,
Let him be ſure he keep him to his Text. Exeunt.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.l: LAdies to you, in whoſe defence and right,
Fletchers brave Muſe prepar'd her ſelf to fight
A battaile without blood, 'twas well fought too,
(The victory's yours, though got with much ado.)
We do preſent this Comedy, in which
A rivulet of pure wit flowes, ſtrong and rich
In Fancy, Language, and all parts that may
Adde grace and ornament to a merry Play.
Which this may prove. Yet not to go too far
In promiſes from this our female war,
We do intreat the angry men would not
Expect the mazes of a ſubtle plot,
Set Speeches, high expreſſions; and what's worſe,
in a true Comedy, politique diſcourſe.
The end we ayme at, is to make you ſport;
Yet neither gall the City, nor the Court.
Heare, and obſerve his Comique ſtraine and when
Y'are ſick of melancholy, ſee't agen.
'Tis no deere Phyſick, ſince 'twill quit the coſt:
Or his intentions, with our pains, are loſt.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.l: THe Tamer's tam'd, but ſo, as nor the men
Can finde one juſt cauſe to complaine of, when
They fitly do conſider in their lives,
They ſhould not raign as Tyrants o'r their wives.
Nor can the women from this preſident
Inſult, or triumph: it being aptly meant,
To teach both Sexes due equality;
And as they ſtand bound, to love mutually.
If this effect, ariſing from a cauſe
Well layd, and grounded, may deſerve applauſe,
We ſomething more then hope, our honeſt ends
Will keep the men, and women too, our friends.
